| CourseCode | CSMC209 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Python Programming |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To learn the basics of Python programming, including syntax, variables, data types, and control flow structures.

• To understand and apply modular programming using functions and modules for efficient code reuse.

• To learn the principles of object-oriented programming in Python, including classes, objects, inheritance, and polymorphism.

• To be able to work with Python’s built-in data structures and perform file handling for data storage and manipulation.

• To explore basic data visualization techniques and libraries like NumPy and Matplotlib for analyzing and representing data.

Overview of Python Programming, Python Installation: Setting up Python, IDEs (Anaconda, Jupyter Notebook, PyCharm), Basic Syntax: Python keywords, variables, comments, and indentation, Data Types and Variables: Integers, floats, strings, type conversions, Operators: Arithmetic, comparison, logical, bitwise, and assignment operators, Input/Output Operations: input(), print(), formatting output

Conditional Statements, Loops, Comprehensions, Functions: Defining functions, arguments (default, keyword, positional), return values, Lambda Functions: Anonymous functions, usage in functional programming, Recursion: Concept and examples, recursion vs iteration, Exception Handling: try, except, finally, raising exceptions.

Lists: Creation, slicing, methods, list comprehensions, Tuples: Characteristics, tuple operations, immutability, Dictionaries: Key-value pairs, dictionary methods, nested dictionaries, Sets: Set operations, unique elements, set methods, Strings: String manipulation, methods, formatting, f-strings, File Handling: Opening, reading, writing, appending files, file modes, Modules and Packages: Importing modules, creating and using packages.

Introduction to OOP: Principles (Encapsulation, Inheritance, Polymorphism), Classes and Objects, Method, Constructors and Destructors, Inheritance, Polymorphism, Encapsulation, Abstract Classes and Interface, File I/O with CSV and JSON, Regular Expressions: Pattern matching, re-module, meta characters, search and match, Introduction to Libraries: NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Web Scraping.

Introduction to Machine Learning, Types of Machine Learning: Supervised, Unsupervised, and Reinforcement Learning, Regression and Classification, Clustering and Dimensionality Reduction , Training, Testing, Overfitting, and Underfitting, Evaluation Metrics: Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-Score, Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Decision Trees, k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN), k-Means.

Familiarize with Python programming, basic syntax, and working with Python in IDEs like Jupyter Notebooks.

Write Python scripts using loops, conditionals, and user-defined functions for modular programming.

Perform reading, writing, and manipulation of files (text and binary) using Python’s builtin file handling techniques.

Explore and work with standard Python libraries like ‘math‘, ‘os‘, and ‘datetime‘ for common programming tasks.

Implement error detection and handling in Python using ‘try‘, ‘except‘, and ‘finally‘ blocks to make robust programs.

Implement sorting and searching algorithms using Python’s list and dictionary data structures.

Develop programs using OOP principles like classes, inheritance, polymorphism, and encapsulation.

Create custom Python modules and use built-in modules for modular programming and code organization.

Perform array operations, matrix manipulations, and basic mathematical computations using the NumPy library.

Use Pandas for data manipulation, including data frames, filtering, grouping, and handling missing values.

Create basic plots, bar charts, histograms, and scatter plots to visualize data using Matplotlib.

Use Seaborn for advanced visualizations, including heatmaps, pair plots, and violin plots.

Implement pattern matching and text processing using Python’s ‘re‘ module for regular expressions.

Learn how to interact with external APIs, fetch data, and process it using Python’s ‘requests‘ module.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the fundamental concepts of Python programming, including syntax, variables,and control structures. | K2 |
| C02 | Apply modular programming techniques using functions and modulesfor code organization and reuse. | K3 |
| C03 | Demonstrate object-oriented programming concepts like classes, inher- itance, and polymorphism to solve problems. | K4 |
| C04 | Utilize Python's data structures and perform file handling operations tomanipulate and store data efficiently. | K3 |
| C05 | Implement basic data analysis and visualization using Python librariessuch as NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib. | K4 |

Python Crash Course (3rd Edition) by Eric Matthes, Publisher: No Starch Press, 2023. 2. Automate the Boring Stuff with Python (2nd Edition) by Al Sweigart, Publisher: No Starch Press, 2021.

Fluent Python: Clear, Concise, and Effective Programming (2nd Edition) by Luciano Ramalho, Publisher: O’Reilly Media, 2022.

Python Programming: An Introduction to Computer Science (3rd Edition) by John Zelle, Publisher: Franklin, Beedle & Associates Inc., 2023.

heading_path: Unit II: Rectifiers and Special Purpose Diodes
content:
| CourseCode | ECMC201 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Electronic Devices and Circuits |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To familiarize with the semiconductor properties and formation of PN Junction diode
• To study the operation and applications of BJT and FET
• To describe the functionality of power semiconductor devices
• To know the switching characteristics of components
• To describe performance analysis of electronic circuits

Classification of semiconductors, Conductivity of semiconductors, Energy distribution of Electrons, Fermi Level, Carrier concentration in an Intrinsic semiconductor, Drift and Diffusion currents, Poisson and Continuity Equations, Theory of PN junction diode, VI characteristics of a PN Junction Diode, Temperature dependence of VI characteristics of diodes, Breakdown in PN junction diodes.

Rectifiers, Half Wave and Full Wave Rectifiers, Clippers (Single and Two Level), Clampers, Analysis with Ideal and Practical Diodes, Special Purpose Diodes: Zener Diode, Tunnel Diode, Varactor Diode, LED, Photo Diode, Schottky Diode.

Unit III: Bipolar Junction Transistor

Transistors: Construction, Operation, Characteristics, Parameters, Transistor as an Amplifier at Low Frequency, Hybrid Model and re-Model of BJT, Analysis of Amplifier using Hybrid Model and re Model, Amplifier Types: CE, CB, CC, DC Operating Point, Biasing Circuits - Fixed Bias, Emitter Bias, Voltage Divider Bias, Bias Stabilization.

Junction FET: Construction, Operation, Characteristics, Parameters, Biasing of JFET, JFET as an Amplifier (Common Source and Common Drain). Construction and Operation of N-Channel and P-Channel MOSFET, Enhancement and Depletion Type MOSFET, Characteristics, Threshold Voltage, Channel Length Modulation, Applications of MOSFETs in CMOS Circuits.

Power Semiconductor Devices: Construction, Principle of Operation, Characteristics and Applications of UJT, PNPN Diode, SCR, LASCR, DIAC, TRIAC, GTO Thyristors, Power BJT, Power MOSFET, DMOS, VMOS.

Study on Oscilloscope, signal generator to view waveforms and measure amplitude and frequency.

Study of V-I characteristics of PN Junction and Zener diodes, and determine its DC and AC resistance.

Study of half-wave and full-wave rectifier circuits without and with capacitor filter.

Study of various clipper and clamper circuits.

Study of V-I characteristics in common-base transistor configuration.

Study of V-I characteristics, DC biasing, and operating point in common-emitter transistor configuration.

Study of BJT fixed bias, self-bias, and voltage divider bias configurations.

Study of Transfer and Drain Characteristics of JFET.

Study of FET fixed bias and self-bias configurations.

Study of Differential Amplifier using BJT.

Study of MOSFET in common source configuration

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Describe the basics of semiconductor physics and working principle ofPN Junction diode. | K2 |
| CO2 | Apply the working principle of special semiconductor devices. | K3 |
| C03 | Analyze the Bipolar Junction Transistor characteristics and the biasingtechniques. | K4 |
| CO4 | Analyze the Field Effect Transistor characteristics and its applications. | K4 |
| C05 | Explain the construction and working principle of power semiconductordevices. | K2 |

Milliman, J., Halkias, C., and Jit, S., “Electronics Devices and Circuits”, 4thedition, McGraw Hill Education, 2015.

Salivahanan, S., and Suresh, N. K., “Electronic Devices and Circuits”, 4th edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Neamen, D. A., and Biswas, D., “Semiconductor physics and devices: basic principles”, 4th edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Sedra, A. S., Smith, K. C., Carusone, T. C., and Gaudet, V. Microelectronic Circuits. Vol. 4. New York: Oxford University Press, 2017.

heading_path: Unit IV: Introduction to State Machines and PLDs
content:
| CourseCode | ECMC202 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Digital circuits and Systems |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To describe the basic principles of digital circuits and solve logic expressions and circuits using Boolean laws and K-map.

• To impart knowledge for the design and implementation of combinational logic circuits.

• To impart knowledge for the design and implementation of sequential logic circuits.

• Classify and comprehend the working principle of logic family and data converters.

• To learn the basics of Verilog HDL for system modeling.

Unit I: Number System And Logic Gates

Introduction to various number systems and their Conversion. Binary Arithmetic (Addition, Subtraction, Multiplication and Division), BCD codes, Excess-3 code, Gray code, Hamming code, Error Detection and Correction. Basic Logic Operations, Basic Identities, Algebraic Laws, Useful Boolean Identities, Canonical Logic Forms, Algebraic Reductions, Complete Logic Sets, Karnaugh Maps.

Concept of a Digital Component, BCD Validity Detector, Binary Adders, Subtractors, Multiplexers, Demultiplexers, Line Decoders and Encoders, Binary Multiplication, Binary Comparators.

Concept of a Sequential Network, Latches, Clock and Synchronization, Flip-Flops, Design of Synchronous & Asynchronous Sequential circuits. Shift registers: Principle of 4-bit shift registers. Shifting principle, Timing Diagram, SISO, SIPO, PISO and PIPO registers.

Algorithmic State Machine, Finite State Machine: Mealy and Moore Machine, Sequence Detector, Vending Machine; Introduction to PLDs, PROM and its types, PAL, and PLA.

Defining Modules in Verilog HDL; Gate, Data Flow and (Behavioral) Structural Modelling, Learning Verilog HDL. CMOS Logic Circuits: NOT Function in CMOS, Complex Logic Gates in CMOS.

Introduction of Digital Logic Gates: Investigate logic behavior of NOT, AND, OR, NAND, NOR, EX-OR, EX-NOR gates.

Gate-level minimization: Two-level and multi-level implementation of Boolean functions.

Combinational Circuits design assemble and test: adders and subtractors.

Code Converter: BCD to Excess-3 code converter, gray code to binary converter, binary to gray code converter.

Design, implement and test a given design example with (i) NAND Gates only (ii) NOR Gates only and (iii) using minimum number of Gates.

Design of multiplexers and de-multiplexers.

Design of encoders and decoders.

Binary Multiplier: design and implement a circuit that multiplies 4-bit unsigned numbers to produce an 8-bit product.

Parallel adder and accumulator: design, implement and test.

Flip-Flop: assemble, test and investigate operation of S-R, D & J-K flip-flops.

Counters: Design, assemble and test various Asynchronous and Synchronous binary counter with parallel load.

Shift Registers: Design and investigate the operation of all types of shift registers with parallel load.

Design of Combinational circuits using the Verilog HDL module.

Design of Sequential circuits using the Verilog HDL module.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |

| C02 | Develop competence in combinational Logic problem formulation andlogic optimization. | K3 |
| CO3 | Develop competence in analysis of synchronous and asynchronous se-quential circuits. | K3 |
| C04 | Compare different types of logic families and data converters | K4 |
| C05 | | K2 |

Thomas L. Floyd. “Digital Fundamentals”, 11th Edition, Pearson International Education, 2017.

Mano, M. M. and Ciletti, M. D. “Digital Design: With an Introduction to the Verilog HDL”, 5th Edition, Pearson Education, 2013.

| CourseCode | ECMC203 |
| --- | --- |
| Course'Title | Signals and Systems |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To learn various types of signals and systems with their properties.

• To compose periodic signals in different forms of Fourier series.

• To analyse the signals using Fourier Transform.

• To get familiar with the concepts of Laplace Transform.

• To analyse the signals using Z-Transform.

Signal Classification (Analog-Digital, Energy-Power, Even-Odd, Periodic-Aperiodic, Deterministic-Random, etc.), Standard Signals (Unit Step, Unit Impulse, Ramp, Exponential, Sinusoids, etc.), Transformations of the Independent Variable (Shifting, Scaling, Reversal), Discrete Unit Step and Impulse Signals and Their Properties. System Classifications (Linearity, Time Invariance, Memory, Causality etc.), Time-Convolution, System Properties via the Impulse Response (Causality, Memory, Stability, Invertibility, Unit Step Response).

History of Fourier Series, Euler to Fourier, Response of LTI Systems to Complex Exponentials and Fourier Series Representation of Continuous Time Periodic Signals, Fourier Series Representation of sawtooth, square and triangular Waves, Gibbs Phenomena, Properties of Fourier Series and Examples, Convergence of Fourier Series, Fourier Series and LTI Systems, Filtering.

Introduction of the Continuous Time Fourier Transform by Taking the Limit of a Periodic Signal (i.e., Making it Aperiodic), Fourier Transforms of Periodic Signals, Properties of Continuous Time Fourier Transforms, Convolution Property of Fourier Transforms, Discrete Time Fourier Transform.

Introduction to Laplace Transform; Region of Convergence, Inverse Laplace Transform, Properties of Laplace transforms, initial/final Value Theorems, Laplace Transforms and LTI systems, causality/stability, Laplace Transforms and Block System Diagrams, Unilateral Laplace Transform and Initial Value Problems.

The $\mathbf { Z }$ -Transform, Properties of z-Transforms, Inversion of z-Transform, One-sided z-Transform, Analysis of Linear Time Invariant Systems in the z-Domain, Convolution of two sequences. Solutions of Difference Equations with Constant Coefficients by $Z -$ transform.

To Write a program to generate the discrete sequences (i) unit step (ii) unit impulse (iii) ramp (iv)periodic sinusoidal sequences. Plot all the sequences.

Write a program to convolve two discrete time sequences. Plot all the sequences. Verify the result by analytical calculation.

Write a program to classify the systems.

Write a program to find the trigonometric Fourier series coefficients of a rectangular periodic signal. Reconstruct the signal by combining the Fourier series coefficients with appropriate weightings.

Write a program to find the polar and exponential Fourier series coefficients of a periodic rectangular signal. Plot the discrete spectrum of the signal.

Find the Fourier transform of a square pulse. Plot its amplitude and phase spectrum.

Write a program to find the Laplace transform of the signals and calculation of ROC.

Write a program to find the $\textsf { Z }$ -transform and inverse $\mathrm { Z }$ -transform of some signals.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain different types of signals and their properties. Apply differentconditions such as Causality, memory requirement, stability, and invert- ibility for checking the type of the system. | K2 |
| C02 | Estimate the periodic signals in different forms of Fourier series. | K2 |
| C03 | Determine the Fourier Transform of signals for finding their response atdifferent frequencies. | K3 |
| C04 | Analyse the unstable systems using Laplace transform. | K3 |
| C05 | Apply concepts of z-transform for analysing the signal properties. | K4 |

Oppenheim, A. V., Willsky, A. S., and Nawab, S. H., “Signals and Systems,” 2nd Edition, Pearson Education, 2015.

Lathi, B. P., “Principles of Linear Systems and Signals,” 2nd Edition, Oxford, 2009.

Haykin, S., “Signals and Systems,” 2nd Edition, Wiley, 2008.

| CourseCode | ECMC204 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Electromagnetic Field Theory |
| LTPC | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To learn fundamentals of vector algebra.
• To study concepts of Electrostatics and Magnetostatics.
• To impart knowledge on Maxwell equations and their applications.
• To study how electromagnetic waves propagate in a medium.
• To study fundamentals of transmission lines and its various characteristics.

Introduction, Scalar fields, Vector fields; Cartesian coordinate system, cylindrical coordinate system, Spherical coordinate system, Transformation from Cylindrical to Spherical Coordinates, Gradient of a Scalar function, Divergence of a vector field, Circulation of a vector and Curl.

Electrostatics, Coulomb’s Law, Electric fields of point charges, Gauss’s Law and applications, Electric potential, Poisson’s and Laplace equations, Method of Images, Multipole Expansion, Electrostatic fields in matter, Dielectrics and electric polarization, Capacitors with dielectric substrates, Magnetostatics: Magnetic fields of steady currents, Biot-Savart’s and Ampere’s Laws, Magnetic vector potential; Magnetic properties of matter, Faraday’s Law.

Equation of continuity for time varying fields. Inconsistency of Amperes law, Maxwell’s equations and their physical interpretation, Maxwell’s Equations in Differential form and Integral form, Interface Conditions for Electromagnetic field, Time-harmonic representation of Maxwell’s equations, Source-free equations.

The Electromagnetic wave equation and its solution, Time-dependent wave equation, TimeHarmonic wave equation, One-Dimensional Wave equation in Free-space and perfect dielectrics; Poynting theorem and electromagnetic power, Complex Poynting vector, Propagation of Plane waves in different materials, Polarization of Plane waves, Normal Incidence on a general dielectric interface, Oblique incidence on dielectric interface for perpendicular and parallel polarization, Brewster’s Angle.

Distributed parameters, Time-domain transmission Line Equations, Types of transmission lines, Finite Transmission lines, Load reflection coefficient, Line impedance and generalized reflection coefficient, Standing wave ratio; Power relations on a generalized transmission line, The Smith chart, Impedance Matching, Stub Matching, Quarter wave transformer matching.

Total Periods: 40

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the fundamentals of vector algebra and apply those in the studyof electromagnetic field theory. | K2 |
| C02 | Analyze the principles of electrostatics and magnetostatics with the helpof different laws. | K4 |
| C03 | Analyze the inconsistency in Ampere's law and formulate Maxwell'sequations in differential and integral forms. | K4 |
| C04 | Identify how electromagnetic waves propagate in any material medium. | K3 |
| C05 | Analyze the principle of flow of V/I waves in a transmission line and study concept of impedance matching. | K4 |

Griffiths, D. J., “Introduction to Electrodynamics”, 4th Edition, Cambridge University Press, 2020.

Nathan, I., “Engineering Electromagnetics”, 2nd Edition, Springer India, 2005.

Verma, H.C., “Classical Electromagnetism”, 1st Edition, Bharati Bhawan Publishers, 2022.

Guru, B. and Hiziroglu, H., “Electromagnetic field theory Fundamentals”, Cambridge University Press, 2005.

Jordon, E. C. and Balmain, K. G., “Electromagnetic waves and Radiating System”, 2nd Edition, Prentice Hall New Delhi, 2007.

| Course Code | ECMC205 |
| --- | --- |
| Course'Title | Network Analysis and Synthesis |
| LTPC | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To under the basic concepts of AC and DC analysis.
• To simplify any network using network theorems.
• To learn the basics of Laplace transform.
• To understand the transient response.
• To analyse any network any two-port network.
• To synthesize any network.
• To analyse a network using graph theory.
• To study the basic filter circuits.

Sinusoids, Phasors, Impedance and admittance, kirchhoff’s law in frequency domain, impedance combinations, steady state analysis: nodal and mesh analysis, dependent, independent voltage and current sources, source transformation, Thevenin and Norton equivalent. AC power analysis: instantaneous and average power, max average power transfer, RMS value, apparent power and power factor, complex power, conservation of AC power. Three phase circuits: types of load and source connections, power in balanced three phase circuits, star delta transformations. Network theorems: compensation, superposition, reciprocity, millman’s and tellegen’s theorem.

Complex frequency and Laplace transforms, circuits analysis in S domain, poles, zeros, transfer Functions and driving point impedances and convolution. Step and impulse response of RL, RC, LC, RLC circuits, initial and final conditions.

Short circuit admittance parameter, open circuit impedance parameters, hybrid and transmission parameters, series parallel and tandem connection of two port networks, multi-port networks, multi terminal networks, indefinite admittance matrix and its properties, relationships among different network parameters.

Elements of realizability theory: causality and stability, Hurwitz polynomials, positive real

functions, elementary synthesis procedure, synthesis of one port network with two kind of element: L-C driving point immittances, synthesis of R-L, L-C functions.

Basic definitions of graph, tree, link, branches, node, topological equations for loop current and node voltages, duality, series and parallel resonance, single and double tuned circuits, passive filters: lowpass, highpass, bandpass and bandstop filters, frequency response.

Total Periods: 40

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Analyze AC and DC circuits (single and three phase) making use ofvarious circuit techniques. | K2 |
| C02 | Learn the frequency domain analysis. | K3 |
| C03 | Acquire knowledge of the fundamentals of network analysis using ma-trices, two-port and multi-port networks, network synthesis and filtercircuits. | K2 |
| C04 | Synthesize a network using various techniques. | K3 |
| C05 | Analyse a network using graph theory. | K3 |
| C06 | Design and observe the characteristics of flter circuits. | K3 |

Alexander, Charles K., Matthew NO Sadiku, and Matthew Sadiku. Fundamentals of electric circuits. Boston: McGraw-Hill Higher Education, 2007.

Van Valkenburg, Mac E. Network analysis. 1974.

Circuit Theory (Analysis and Synthesis), authored by A. Chakrabarti

Engineering Circuit Analysis by William H. Hayt, Jr., Jack E. Kemmerly, and Steven M. Durbin

Van Valkenburg, Mac E. Network analysis. 1974.

| CourseCode | ECMC206 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | DesignEngineering |
| LTPC | 0-0-4-2 |
| Course Type | MC |

• Learn to use circuit design and simulation tools such as OrCAD, PSpice, and other relevant software.

• Gain hands-on experience in digital and analog circuit simulation, PCB design, and schematic capture.

• Develop engineering thinking for problem solving, design validation, and prototype simulation.

• Bridge the gap between theory and real-world system design using software-based experimentation.

• Familiarize students with key tools used in AI/ML, IoT, and Robotics design and simulation.

• Enable end-to-end prototyping with sensors, embedded systems, and ML models.

• Strengthen design thinking and interdisciplinary skills through hands-on mini projects.

Introduction to Circuit Design Tools – Overview of OrCAD & PSpice:

Students will be introduced to Electronic Design Automation (EDA) tools—OrCAD and PSpice—for designing, simulating, and analyzing electronic circuits. The session covers workspace setup, component libraries, and simulation flow.

DC and AC Circuit Simulation:

Students will simulate basic DC and AC circuits using PSpice, observe voltage-current relationships, and verify Ohm’s and Kirchhoff’s laws. Frequency response and phase analysis of RLC circuits are also included.

Analog Components Simulation:

Simulation of analog components like diodes, BJTs, op-amps, and MOSFETs. Emphasis is placed on understanding I-V characteristics, amplifier configurations, and nonlinear behavior.

Digital Logic Design:

Using digital libraries in simulation tools, students design and test logic gates, combinational circuits (e.g., adders, multiplexers), and validate truth tables and Boolean equations.

Timing Analysis& Sequential Circuits:

Focus on timing diagrams and sequential logic circuits such as flip-flops, counters, and registers. Timing simulation and clock pulse behavior are studied using PSpice.

Microcontroller Simulation Basics:

Introduction to simulating microcontrollers in software (e.g., Proteus). Basics of memory, I/O control, and simple embedded routines using LEDs and switches are practiced.

PCB Design Principles:

Students learn about schematic capture, PCB layout, netlist generation, routing, and design rule checks. The experiment emphasizes the complete process of translating circuit diagrams to physical PCBs.

Project Ideation & Block Diagram Design :

Students brainstorm project ideas in groups and prepare functional block diagrams. Concepts of modularity, functional division, and signal flow are emphasized.

Design Project Implementation – Part 1: Initial phase of hardware implementation: component selection, microcontroller programming, breadboard testing, and partial circuit realization.

Design Project Implementation – Part 2:

Final project integration: assembling the entire circuit/system, debugging, testing outputs, and validating functionality as per block diagrams.

Project Demo & Viva:

Groups present and demonstrate their projects, followed by individual viva sessions.
Evaluation includes innovation, working model, documentation, and presentation.

Introduction to AI/ML, IoT & Robotics – Concept Mapping, Group Ideation: Overview session on the convergence of AI, ML, IoT, and robotics. Concept mapping and ideation exercises are conducted to explore interdisciplinary project possibilities.

Python Basics for ML $^ +$ Intro to Jupyter – Jupyter Notebook, scikit-learn: Hands-on with Python syntax, data types, loops, and functions. Introduction to Jupyter Notebook for coding and data visualization, and use of scikit-learn for basic ML tasks.

ML for Engineers – Classification Models – Teachable Machine or scikit-learn: Students train classification models using either Teachable Machine or scikit-learn. Topics include data collection, training, testing, and performance metrics like accuracy and confusion matrix.

IoT Introduction $^ +$ Arduino Sensor Interfacing – Arduino IDE, DHT11/IR Sensors: Introduction to IoT architecture and basic interfacing of sensors (e.g., DHT11 for temperature/humidity, IR for object detection) using Arduino. Coding via Arduino IDE.

NodeMCU/ESP32 Programming $^ +$ Cloud Integration – ThingSpeak, Blynk, Firebase: IoT data transmission using NodeMCU/ESP32 with real-time cloud platforms. Students learn to send data to ThingSpeak, visualize on Blynk dashboard, and log to Firebase.

Robotics: Actuators & Sensor Integration – Motor Drivers, Ultrasonic Sensors: Basics of robotics including actuator (DC/servo motor) control and sensor (ultrasonic) feedback. Students build simple obstacle detection setups using L298N driver modules.

Line Follower or Obstacle Avoider Bot – Arduino $^ +$ IR Sensors: Students design and implement a basic autonomous robot. Line following logic or obstacle avoidance using IR sensors and Arduino is developed and tested.

IoT Dashboard & Data Visualization: Students create custom IoT dashboards using tools like Blynk, ThingSpeak, or Google Sheets. Emphasis is on real-time plotting, alerts, and controlling devices remotely.

$\mathbf { M L } + \mathbf { I o } \mathbf { T }$ : Smart Prediction System – ESP32 + onboard ML using TensorFlow Lite: A complete project integrating machine learning models into IoT devices. ESP32 is used to run ML models (e.g., motion detection, air quality prediction) using TensorFlow Lite.

Introduction to AI/ML, IoT & Robotics – Concept Mapping, Group Ideation: Final ideation session to consolidate all concepts learned throughout the course. Students brainstorm future project ideas that combine AI, ML, IoT, and robotics in practical usecases.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | To introduce students to electronic circuit design and simulation tools such as OrCAD and PSpice | K1 |
| C02 | To develop skills in microcontroller programming and sensor interfac- ing using platforms like Arduino, ESP32,and NodeMCU for embeddedsystem applications. | K2 |
| CO3 | To impart knowledge of PCB design principles and guide students through the complete design cycle from ideation to hardware imple-mentation. | K3 |
| C04 | To introduce the fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence and MachineLearning using Python and scikit-learn | K3 |
| C05 | To enable students to integrate IoT with AI/ML and robotics by building smart systems using cloud platforms | K4 |

S. W. Smith, The Scientist and Engineer’s Guide to Digital Signal Processing, 1st ed. San Diego, CA, USA: California Technical Publishing, 1997.

A. Bahga and V. Madisetti, Internet of Things: A Hands-On Approach, 1st ed. Atlanta, GA, USA: VPT, 2014.

C. Platt, Make: Electronics: Learning Through Discovery, 2nd ed. San Francisco, CA, USA: Maker Media, 2015.

S. Raschka and V. Mirjalili, Python Machine Learning, 3rd ed. Birmingham, U.K.: Packt Publishing, 2019.

| CourseCode | ECMC207 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Microwave Engineering |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To learn fundamentals of microwaves.
• To represent microwave network using scattering matrix.
• To impart knowledge on microwave waveguides and components.
• To study design consideration and principle of operation of microwave tubes.
• To study various microwave semiconductor devices and their applications.

History of Microwaves, Microwave Frequency bands, General Applications of Microwaves, Advantages of Microwaves, Mathematical model of Microwave Transmission, Microwave Propagation (Friis Free space propagation model), Losses associated with microwave transmission, Concept of Impedance in Microwave transmission.

Analysis of Parallel plane waveguides, Rectangular waveguides and Circular waveguides, Rectangular cavity resonator, Microwave Hybrid circuits, Waveguide Tees, Magic tees, Rat-race circuits, Directional coupler, Circulators and Isolators, Wilkinson power divider.

Equivalent voltages and currents, concept of impedance, impedance and admittance matrices of microwave junctions, scattering matrix representation of microwave networks, ABCD parameters, excitation techniques for waveguides.

Design considerations and current status of microwave tubes, principle of operation of multicavity and reflex klystron, magnetron and traveling wave tube, Applications of Microwave tubes, Operation and circuit applications of Gunn diode, IMPATT diode, PIN Diode, and Schottky barrier diode, HEMT and their applications.

Introduction to antennas, Radiation mechanism and Current distribution of single wire, two wire, and dipole, Types of antennas and their applications, Isotropic radiators, Fundamental antenna parameters.

To study I-V characteristics of Gunn diode.

To study the output power and frequency as a function of voltage characteristic of G
diode.

To study square wave modulation through Pin diode.

To study the characteristics of Reflex Klystron Tube.

Measurement of Directional Coupler parameters.

To study characteristics of Isolator and Circulator.

To study characteristics of Waveguide Tees.

Measurement of Frequency and Wavelength.

Measurement of Impedance.

Antenna Measurements.

Low, medium and high VSWR measurements.

To study the variable attenuator.

To study voice communication using Microwave test bench.

To study the square law behavior of microwave crystal detector.

To design Microstrip patch antenna using CST microwave studio.

To design Vivaldi antenna using CST microwave studio.

To design Anti-Podal Vivaldi antenna using CST microwave studio.

To design a Frequency selective surface for X-band using CST microwave studio.

| C03 | Analyze the basic mechanism behind the wave propagation in waveg-uides. | K4 |
| C04 | Identify the effect of microwaves on different parts of human body and study operating principles of microwave tubes. | K3 |
| C05 | Assess the methods used for generation and amplification of microwavepower. | K5 |

heading_path: Unit II: AM Transmitters and Receivers
content:
| CourseCode | ECMC208 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | AnalogCommunication |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To understand the concepts of analog modulation and demodulation techniques with the performance of AM, FM and PM schemes.

• To know the design characteristics of Amplitude modulation transmitter and receiver systems.

• To understand the Frequency modulation transmitter and receiver systems.

• To introduce the concepts of various pulse modulation techniques and their demodulation.

• To study the different types of noises in communication systems.

Various frequency bands used for communication, Types of Communication and need of modulation. Introduction to AM, FM, PM, frequency spectrum of AM Waves, Representation of AM, Power relation in AM waves, Need and description of SSB, Suppression of carrier, Suppression of unwanted side-bands, Independent sideband system, Vestigial sideband system, Mathematical representation of FM, Frequency spectrum of AM waves, wideband and narrow band FM, Phase Modulation.

AM Transmitters: Generation of AM, low level and high level modulation, AM transmitter block diagram, collector class C modulator, Base Modulator, DSB-SC modulator. Generator of SSB, balanced modulator circuit, filter method, phase shift method, third method, Phase cancellation method. AM Receivers: Tuned radio frequency (TRF) receiver. Super heterodyne receiver, RF section and characteristics, mixers, frequency changing and tracking, IF rejection and IF amplifiers. Detection and automatic gain control (AGC), AM receiver characteristics, Demodulation of SSB, product demodulator, Diode detection technique of SSB.

FM Transmitters: Generation of FM, FM Modulation methods: Direct methods (Variable capacitor Modulator, Varactor Diode Modulator, FET Reactance Modulator, Transistor Reactance Modulator, AFC in reactance modulator), Disadvantages of direct method, Indirect modulators (RC-phase shift modulators, Armstrong FM systems). FM Receivers: Limiters, single and double-tuned demodulators (balanced slope detector, Foster-Seeley or Phase Discriminator, ratio Detector, FM Detector using PLL), Pre-emphasis and De-emphasis, Block diagram of FM

Receivers, RF Amplifiers, FM Receiver characteristics, Phase modulator and demodulator circuits.

Pulse amplitude modulation and demodulation, Pulse width modulation and demodulation, Pulse position modulation and demodulation, Sampling theorem, Time Division Multiplexing, Frequency Division Multiplexing.

Thermal Noise, Shot noise, Partition noise, Flicker noise, Gaussian Noise, Noise in Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJTs), FET noise. Equivalent input noise, Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR), Noise Temperature, Noise equivalent Bandwidth, Noise Figure. Experimental determination of Noise Figure, Pulse Response and its elimination.

To study Amplitude Modulation/demodulation using a transistor, depth of modulation, and observe the diagonal peak clipping effect of AM.

Frequency Modulation using Voltage Controlled Oscillator.

Generation of DSB-SC, SSB, and VSB.

Study of Phase Lock Loop (PLL) and detection of FM Signal using PLL.

Study functioning of Super-heterodyne AM Receiver, and study the limiter circuit and IF filter frequency response, study of the effect of image frequency.

Study functioning of Super-heterodyne FM Receiver

Measurement of Sensitivity, Selectivity, and Fidelity of radio receivers.

Study of PAM, PPM, and PPM.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Analyze and compare different types of modulation and demodulationschemes for their efficiency and bandwidth. | K2 |
| C02 | Attain in-depth knowledge of different Transmitters and Receivers de-sign of amplitude modulation | K3 |
| C03 | Attain in-depth knowledge of different Transmitters and Receivers de- sign of frequency modulation. | K3 |
| C04 | Compare different pulse modulation and multiplexing techniques | K3 |
| C05 | Apply concepts of noises in designing of communication systems. | K2 |

Haykin S., “Communications Systems”, John Wiley and Sons, 2001.

B. P. Lathi, “Modern Digital and Analog Communication Systems,” 4th Edition, Oxford, 2011.

Tomasi, W., “Advanced Electronic Communications systems” 6th Edition, Pearson Publishers, 2015.

Taub H. and Schilling D.L., ”Prnciples of Communication Systems”, Tata McGraw Hill, 2001.

| Course Type | MC |

• To understand microprocessor evolution, architecture, and applications, focusing on Intel 8085.

• To learn the development of assembly language programming of 8085.

• To learn essential data transfer methods for microprocessor-based systems.

• To learn the Interfacing of 8085 microprocessor with various peripherals.

History and Evolution, Types of microprocessors, Microcomputer programming languages, Microcomputer architecture, Intel 8085 Microprocessor, Pin Diagram, Architecture Diagram, Addressing Modes, Instruction Format, Types of Instructions, Instruction Set of 8085.

Assembly Language Programming in 8085, Macros, Labels and Directives, Microprocessor timings, Micro Instructions, Instruction Cycle, Machine Cycle, T-states, state transition Diagrams, Timing diagrams for different machine cycles. INTERRUPTS: Interrupts in 8085, Issues in implementing interrupts, Multiple Interrupts and priorities, Interrupt handling in 8085, enabling, disabling, and masking of interrupts.

Data transfer techniques, Introduction to PPI 8255, Programmable Interval Timer/Counter 8253, Programmable Interrupt Controller (8259), DMA Controller (8257), USART (8251).

Interfacing Traffic Light Interface, Stepper Motor, 4 Digit 7 Segment LED, Elevator, Musical Tone Generator and 8 Channel 12Bit ADC with Multiplexor and A/D converters, D/A converters.

WAP using 8085 Microprocessor for Decimal, Hexadecimal addition and subtraction of two Numbers.

WAP to write a program to arrange an array of data in ascending and descending order.

WAP to initiate 8251 and to check the transmission and reception of character.

Parallel communication between two microprocessors kits using 8255.

Serial communications between two microprocessors kits using 8251.

To interface DAC with 8085 to demonstrate the generation of square, saw tooth and triangular Wave.

Program for sorting an array for 8086.

Program to find the factorial of a given number.

Programs for searching a number or character in a string for 8086.

Programs for string manipulation for 8086.

heading_path: Unit IV: Active Filters and Oscillators Using OP-AMP
content:
| CourseCode | ECMC210 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Linear Integrated Circuits |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To learn the fundamentals of BJT Amplifiers.
• To learn the fundamentals of multistage and differential amplifiers.
• To learn general operational amplifiers and linear applications of Op-Amp.
• To impart knowledge on active filters and oscillators.
• To study special IC applications using Op-Amp.

Introduction of Biasing of BJT, BJT Amplifier using re, $\pi$ and Hybrid- $\pi$ Model; Common Emitter, Common Collector, and Common base, Requirement of Frequency Response, Low and High Frequency Response of BJT Amplifiers.

Multistage Amplifiers, Types of multistage couplings. Feedback Amplifier; Concept of feedback, Analysis of various configurations of feedback in amplifiers; Current mirror and current sources, Current sources as active loads, BJT Differential amplifier with active loads.

Introduction to operational amplifiers, the ideal Op-Amp, Ideal Voltage Transfer curve, Openloop Op-Amp configurations, Characteristics of practical Op-Amp; The peaking amplifier, Summing, Scaling and Averaging amplifiers, Voltage Follower, Differential input and Differential output amplifier, V-to-I with Floating load and Grounded load, I-to-V converters, Instrumentation amplifier, Integrator, Differentiator, Logarithmic amplifier, Antilogarithmic amplifier.

Active filters, First-order and second order Butterworth filters; Low pass and High pass, Band pass filters, Band-reject filters, All-pass filter, Oscillators; Principles, Types, Phase shift oscillator, Wein Bridge oscillator, Basic Comparator, Schmitt Trigger, Zero-crossing detector, Astable Multivibrator and Monostable Multivibrator (using op-amp).

The 555 Timer; as a monostable multivibrator, as a astable multivibrator, IC Voltage regulators – Three terminal fixed and adjustable voltage regulators, IC 723 general purpose regulator,

Monolithic switching regulator, Frequency to Voltage and Voltage to Frequency converters, Phase-Locked loops.

Design and testing of inverting and non-inverting operational amplifiers.

To verify the function of an operational amplifier as an adder and subtractor.

To demonstrate the integrator and differentiator circuits using Op-amp.

Design and testing Instrumentation amplifier.

Design and testing active low-pass, high-pass, band-pass and band-stop filters.

Design and testing of astable and mono-stable multi-vibrators using Op-amp.

Design and testing Schmitt Trigger and Comparator using Op-amp.

Design, Build and Test a Square wave and triangular wave generators using op-amp.

To study the operation of IC 565 as PLL.

Study of Multiplier IC.

To study the output characteristics of half-wave and full-wave rectifier using op-amp.

Above experiments are to be Simulated using SPICE.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the working of BJT Amplifiers and study its frequency re-sponse. | K2 |
| C02 | Infer the DC and AC characteristics of multistage amplifiers and explaintheir effect on the output. | K2 |
| C03 | Explain the working of general-purpose OP-AMP and design the gen- eral linear applications of an OP-AMP. | K6 |
| C04 | Examine the functionality of various active filters and oscillators. | K4 |
| C05 | Design application specific ICs such as Voltage regulators,PLL anddetermine their applications in modern day communication systems. | K6 |

Gayakwad, R. A., “OP-AMP and Linear Integrated Circuits”, 4th Edition, Pearson Education, 2015.

Franco, S., “Design with Operational Amplifiers and Analog Integrated Circuits”, 4th Edition, McGraw-Hill education, 2016.

Choudhary, D. R. and Jain, S. B., “Linear Integrated Circuits”, 5th Edition, New Age International, 2018.

| Course Code | ECMC211 |
| --- | --- |
| Course'Title | Control Systems |
| LTPC | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To acquire the knowledge of the dynamic modelling of the systems and their representations.

• To analyse the time domain behaviour of the control systems.

• To analyse the open and closed loop stability.

• To analyse the frequency domain behaviours and design control systems using different classical control theory.

• To understand the concept of state variable analysis.

Historical review, Definitions, Classification, Relative merits and demerits of open and closed loop systems, Linear and non-linear systems, Transfer function, Mathematical modelling of electrical, Mechanical and thermal systems, Analogies, Block diagrams and signal flow graphs, Control System Components.

Importance of time response in transient and steady state analysis, typical test input signals, transient response of the first order and second order system, time response specifications, dominant closed loop poles of higher order systems, steady state error and error coefficients, PID Control-Analytical design for P, PI, PID control systems.

Concepts of absolute and relative stability, pole zero location, Routh Hurwitz criteria. Relative Stability-Root Locus Concept-Guidelines for sketching root locus- Nyquist stability criterion.

Closed loop frequency Response-Performance specification in frequency domain- Frequency response of standard second order system- Bode Plot — Polar Plot- Nyquist Plots. Design of compensators using Bode plots, lead compensation, lag compensation, lag-lead compensation.

Concept of State, State variables & state models, State space representation of linear continuous time systems, State models for linear continuous time systems, State variables and linear discrete time systems, Solution of state equations, Concept of controllability & observability

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain and distinguish between open and closed control systems. | K2 |
| C02 | Compute the transfer function of the mathematical model of a givenphysical system. | K3 |
| C03 | Distinguish the various type of control system hardware and their func-tionality. | K2 |
| C04 | Analyze and measure the response and stability of the closed and openloop systems. | K5 |
| C05 | Design various kinds of controllers and compensators and then comparetheir performance. | K6 |

Nagrath, I. J. and Gopal, M., “Control System Engineering,” 7th Edition, New Age International, 2021.

Nise, Norman S., “Control Systems Engineering” 8th Edition, John Wiley& Sons, 2019.

Warwick, K., “An Introduction to Control Systems”, 2nd Edition, World Scientific Publishing, 1996.

Astr ˚ om, K. J. and Murray, R.M. “Feedback systems. An Introduction for Scientists and¨ Engineers”. 2008.

| CourseCode | ECMC212 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Digital Signal Processing |
| LTPC | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To study the basics of Signal representation and discrete systems.
• To understand the analytical tools such as Fourier transforms, Discrete Fourier transforms and Fast Fourier Transforms required for digital signal processing.
• To understand the digital filters for digital signal processing.
• To design and realize various IIR and FIR.

Signal and its classification, basic elements of digital signal processing, advantages of digital signal processing over analog processing, correlation of signals.

Discrete Fourier Transform: frequency domain sampling of DTFT, DFT as linear transformation, properties of DFT, circular convolution, discrete time signal analysis using DFT, introduction to FFT: minimum complexity space for DFT, decimation in time and decimation in frequency methods to compute FFT algorithm, Goertzel algorithm.

Introduction to recursive and non-recursive systems, structural look of LTI systems, recursive and non-recursive realization of FIR systems, basic FIR digital filter structures: direct and cascade form structures, lattice structures, linear phase FIR systems, IIR digital filter structures: direct and cascade form, parallel and lattice structures.

Introduction, General considerations: causality and Paley-Wiener theorem, characteristics of frequency selective filters, design of linear phase FIR filters using windowed Fourier series and frequency sampling method.

Introduction, design of IIR filters from analog filters, IIR filter design via approximation of derivatives, impulse invariance, bilinear transformation and matched z-transformation.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| Co | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Summarize the fundamentals of different signals and basic operationsof Signal processing. | K2 |
| C02 | Understand the handling of discrete/digital signals using MATLAB. | K2 |
| C03 | Analyse the spectral components of discrete signals. | K4 |
| C04 | Implement FIR/IIR systems using efficient structures. | K3 |
| C05 | Design FIR/IR systems for given specifications. | K3 |

Proakis, J. G. and Manolakis, D. G., “Digital Signal Processing: Principles, Algorithms and Applications”, 4th Edition, Pearson education, 2014.

Mitra, S. K., “Digital Signal Processing: A computer-based approach”, 4th Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2013.

Tan, L. and Jiang, J., “Digital Signal Processing: Fundamentals and Applications”, 2nd edition, Academic Press, 2013.

Oppenheim, A. V. and Schafer, R. W., “Discrete-Time Signal Processing”, 3rd edition, Pearson Education, 2014.

Andreas Antoniou (2006), “Digital Signal Processing”, Tata McGraw Hill, New Delhi.

Ifeachor and Jervis, “Digital Signal Processing”, Pearson Education India.

| Course Code | ECMC213 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Product Development Lab |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 0-0-2-1 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To introduce students to PCB design tools and techniques.
• To familiarize students with the process of converting a schematic design into a physical prototype.
• To enhance students’ understanding of CAD tools and their role in prototyping.
• To enable students to integrate and test basic electronic components using prototyping techniques.
• To develop the practical skills on designing the real-world circuits.

Overview of PCB design, types of PCBs, applications, materials used, and design considerations. Introduction to PCB design software.

Exploration of the PCB design software: Symbols and footprints, component library management. Design and simulation of basic circuits.

PCB stack-up, routing strategies, grounding techniques, component placement, and design rules. Designing single-layer and double-layer PCBs, performing ERC (Electrical Rule Check) and DRC (Design Rule Check).

PCB manufacturing process, CAM files (Gerber files), via types, solder mask, silkscreen, soldering techniques, and safety. Generating Gerber files, preparing PCB for fabrication, printing and etching PCB prototypes, Hand soldering components, placing and soldering surface mount components, and assembling the PCB

Testing procedures for continuity, voltage, and functionality; debugging and troubleshooting techniques. Functional testing of the PCB; identifying and correcting issues

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Understand and utilize PCB design software to create schematics andPCB layouts | K1 |
| C02 | Design a PCB using CAD tools and prepare necessary documentation. | K4 |
| C03 | Fabricate a PCB prototype by implementing design-for-manufacturingprinciples. | K5 |
| C04 | Assemble and solder components on a PCB and perform functional test-ing. | K3 |
| C05 | Identify and troubleshoot design and assembly errors effectively | K2 |

Khandpur, Raghbir Singh. ”Printed Circuit Boards Design, Fabrication, and Assembly.” (2006).

Mitzner, Kraig. Complete PCB design using OrCAD Capture and PCB editor. Newnes, 2009.

Wilson, Peter. The circuit designer’s companion. Newnes, 2017.

Eppinger, Steven D., and Karl Ulrich. ”Product design and development.” (1995).

heading_path: Unit IV: Information Theory and Source Coding
content:
| CourseCode | ECMC301 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Digital Communication |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• Familiarize students with fundamental concepts in digital communications, including signal processing and basics in random process

• Introduce students to various digital transmission systems, such as baseband transmission and passband transmission.

• Discuss the effects of noise on digital communication systems and various channel characteristics.

• Describe the principles information theory and various coding techniques

• Provide practical, hands-on experience with simulation tools, software-defined radio platforms to enhance students’ understanding of digital communication principles.

Geometric representation of signals, Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization, Introduction to random variables, joint probability density function, characteristic functions, derived distributions, Introduction to random processes, Gaussian process, Linear functional of random process, Stationary and wide sense stationary random process, Power spectral density, White Gaussian noise.

Pulse code modulation (PCM), PCM Generation and Reconstruction, Quantization Noise, NonUniform Quantization and Commanding, Differential and adaptive PCM, Noise considerations in PCM, Delta modulation and demodulation, slope overload, Adaptive and Sigma Delta Modulation.

Generation and detection of coherent & non-coherent Amplitude, Frequency & Phase Shift Keying (ASK, FSK, PSK), Quadrature modulation techniques, Minimum Shift Keying (MSK), M-ary FSK, Optimal receiver and Probability of error, comparison of various digital modulation techniques, Coherent reception of ASK, PSK and FSK, Non-Coherent reception of ASK, FSK, PSK and QPSK.

Definition of Information, Entropy, Mutual Information, Properties of Mutual Information, Relationship between entropy and mutual information, Types of Channels, Binary Symmetric Channel, Channel Capacity, Channel Coding Theorem, Shannon-Hartley Theorem, Kraft inequality, Huffman codes, Shannon-Fano coding.

Linear Block Codes, Systematic linear codes and optimum decoding for the binary symmetric channel, Generator and Parity Check matrices, Syndrome decoding on symmetric channels; Hamming codes, Weight enumerators and the Mac-Williams identities; Perfect codes. Cyclic Codes, BCH codes, Convolution codes, Turbo codes.

Study of line coding techniques.

Study of sampling theorem.

Study of pulse code modulation and demodulation.

Study of delta modulation and demodulation, the effect of slope overload.

Study pulse data coding techniques for NRZ and RZ formats.

Study of Binary modulation schemes: ASK, PSK, and FSK.

Study of M-ary modulation schemes: QPSK, MSK and QAM modulator and demodula
tor.

Study of channel coding schemes.

Study of multiplexing technique such as CDMA.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Demonstrate the understanding of basic concepts in digital communi-cations, including signal processing and random process | K2 |
| C02 | Apply knowledge of various digital modulation techniques to design and implement communication systems | K3 |
| C03 | Analyse the performance of digital communication systems, includingmetrics such as bit error rate (BER), signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), andbandwidth efficiency | K4 |
| C04 | Explain the concept of information, entropy,and describe various datacompression coding techniques | K2 |
| C05 | Design and implement error control coding techniques to detect andcorrect errors in transmitted data | K5 |

John G. Proakis and Masoud Salehi, “Fundamentals of Communication Systems,” Pearson Education India, 2007.

Simon Haykin, “Communications Systems,” John Wiley, 2008.

Peebles, P. Z., “Probability Random Variables and Random Signal Principles”, 4th Edition, Mc-Graw Hill Education, 2018.

B.P. Lathi and Z. Ding, “Modern Digital and Analog Communication Systems”, Oxford Press, 5th edition, 2018

Taub, H. and Schilling, D. L., “Principles of communication systems,” 4th Edition, McGraw Hill India, 2012.

| Course Code | ICAE301 |
| --- | --- |
| Course Title | Professional Communication and Soft Skills |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 0-0-4-2 |
| Course Type | AE |

• To promote theoretical understanding and professional/personal practice of effective and ethical human communication between and within a broad range of contexts and communities.

• To develop awareness about different forms of professional communication and social behavior in a team and as a team.

• To hone the employability related communication skills of the students by empowering them with appropriate language usage for presentation delivery, interviews, and public speaking.

• To deal professionally through the art of negotiation.

• To instill confidence to speak in public and do group discussions.

Aspects of Soft Skills: Effective Communication Skills, Personality Development, Importance of Professional Ethics.

Understanding nature of team: Mapping personal and professional goals of team members, Working effectively in a team through building relations and interpersonal communication. What is negotiation, Ways of negotiating, Understanding the power of language and non-verbal communication.

How to call a meeting, how to organize a meeting, how to design the agenda and prepare minutes of the meeting. Researching for a presentation, structure of presentation, verbs often required, language focus, importance of body language in presentation, preparing an outline of a presentation, ending the presentation.

Kinds of stress, Identifying the right reasons of stress, how to handle the pressure, Techniques to cope with the stressful situation at a workplace, Goal setting, Understand the importance of time and how to prepare the time line.

Nature of discussion, Ways to form and present the arguments, public speaking skills and being successful in it.

IIITUGECE24

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| Co | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Develop awareness about personality development, social behavior andprofessional ethics. | K3 |
| C02 | Understand and recognize the importance of interpersonal skills and team dynamics,and strengthen individual expression in collaborativepeer activities. | K3 |
| C03 | Apply concepts of negotiation to a workplace situation and effectivelyplan a negotiation using appropriate verbal and nonverbal cues. | K3 |
| C04 | Plan and execute Meetings, and draft minutes, reports and relevant doc-uments. | K3 |
| C05 | Develop coherence, cohesion and competence essential for presentationdeliveries. | K3 |

Rizvi, M. A., “Effective Technical Communication” , 2nd edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Mohan, K. and Banerji, M., “Developing Communication Skills” , 2nd edition, Laxmi Publications, 2009.

Markel, M and Selber, S.A., “Technical Communication”, 12th Edition, Macmillan Learning, 2018.

Dale, C., “How to Win Friends and Influence People”, New York: Simon and Schuster, 1998.

Coleman, D., “Emotional Intelligence”. Bantam Book, 2006.

Thorpe, E., and Thorpe, S., “Objective English”, Pearson Education, New Delhi, 2007.

Tyagi, V.K. and Tyagi, B, “Soft Skills for Engineers & Professionals, , First Edition, BlueRose Publishers Pvt. Ltd. , 21 July 2022.

• To enable the students to create on awareness on Engineering Ethics and Human Values, to instil Moral and Social Values and loyalty and to appreciate the rights of others.

• To develop and prompt the accountability and responsibility being engineering professional.

• To enable students to identify and analyze ethical dilemmas in their professional lives and make informed, principled decisions.

• To guide students in adhering to professional codes of conduct and industry standards, ensuring that their behavior positively reflects on their profession and organization.

• To cultivate an appreciation for diverse perspectives, cultures, and practices, ensuring respectful and equitable treatment of all individuals in a professional setting.

Morals, values and Ethics, Integrity, Work ethic, Service learning, Civic virtue, Respect for others, Living peacefully, Caring, Sharing, Honesty, Courage, Valuing time, Cooperation, Commitment, Empathy, Self-confidence, Character, Spirituality: Introduction to Yoga and meditation for professional excellence and stress management.

Senses of ‘Engineering Ethics’, Variety of moral issues, Types of inquiry, Moral dilemmas, Moral Autonomy, Kohlberg’s theory, Gilligan’s theory, Consensus and Controversy, Models of professional roles, Theories about right action, Self-interest, Customs and Religion, Uses of Ethical Theories

Engineering as Experimentation, Engineers as responsible Experimenters, Codes of Ethics, A Balanced Outlook on Law.

Safety and Risk, Assessment of Safety and Risk, Risk Benefit Analysis and Reducing Risk, Respect for Authority, Collective Bargaining, Confidentiality, Conflicts of Interest, Occupational Crime, Professional Rights, Employee Rights, Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) – Importance of Plagiarism, Discrimination

Multinational Corporations, Environmental Ethics, Computer Ethics, Weapons Development, Engineers as Managers, Consulting Engineers, Engineers as Expert Witnesses and Advisors, Moral Leadership, Code of Conduct, Corporate Social Responsibility

Total Periods: 40

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Distinguish between ethical and non-ethical situations. | K4 |
| C02 | Practice moral judgment effectively handling the conditions ofdilemma. | K3 |
| C03 | Develop cognitive skills in solving social problems and apply the codeof ethics to social experimentation. | K3 |
| C04 | Apply risk and safety measures in various engineering fields. | K3 |
| C05 | Explain corporate social responsibility and understand the concern forethical contribution for the global society. | K2 |

Govindarajan M., Natarajan S., Senthilkumar V.S., “Engineering Ethics”, Prentice Hall of India, 2013.

Martin Mike W., Schinzinger Roland, “Ethics in engineering”, Tata Mc Graw Hill, 4th Editin,2005.

Ferrell, O. C., Fraedrich, J., & Ferrell, L. (2005). Business ethics: Ethical decision making and cases (13th ed.). Cengage Learning. 2. Singer, P., & Singer, F. A. (2008). Ethics for the real world: Creating a personal code to guide decisions in work and life. Harvard Business Review Press. 3. Brenkert, G. G. (2004). Corporate integrity and accountability. SAGE Publications.

| Course Code | ICHC301 |

| Course'Title | Honours Online Course- I* |

| CourseCode | ICOC301 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Optional Online Course- I* |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | X-X-X-(0-3) |
| CourseType | OC |

The Students can opt for Optional Online Course along with their normal courses. The students can choose online courses from NPTEL/SWAYAM/MOOCs. In Optional course the credit will not be counted for the calculation of the final CGPA but the credit will appear in the Grade card and transcript.

| Course Code | ECMC302 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | VLSI DESIGN |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MC |

• To get familiar with emerging VLSI technology and MOS transistor.
• To learn about the various fundamentals used in the design of CMOS logic circuits.
• To understand the concepts related to design of digital CMOS logic circuits.
• To learn about the design techniques for Sequential MOS Logic Circuits.
• To study various low power techniques for CMOS circuits.

Need of VLSI, Design Flow, Concept of Regularity, Modularity and Locality, VLSI Design Styles, Computer-Aided Design Technology, MOS Transistor theory: Basic MOS Transistors, MOSFET operation in Enhancement Mode and depletion mode, The MOSFET Transistor regions of operation Accumulation, Depletion and Strong Inversion, The Threshold voltage, I-V Characteristic of MOSFET.

Voltage Transfer Characteristic (VTC), Noise Immunity and Noise Margin, MOS Inverters: Resistive-Load Inverters, CMOS Inverter, Switching Characteristics and Interconnect Effects, Delay-Time Definitions, Rise time, fall time, Calculation of Delay-Times, Switching Power Dissipation of CMOS Inverters.

Static CMOS Logic Gates (NAND and NOR), Psuedo NMOS, Dynamic Logic Circuits, Basic Principles of Pass Transistor Circuits, Transmission Gates, High Performance Dynamic CMOS Circuits, Domino Circuits.

Introduction, Static Latches and Registers, Dynamic Latches and Registers, Flip flop and latch timings, SR, JK, D, and Master-slave flip flop, Pulse based Registers, Sense Amplifier Based registers, MOS Memories, DRAM and SRAM.

Need for low power VLSI chips, Sources of power dissipation (Switching, Short and Leakage Power Dissipation), Low-Power Design techniques (VTCMOS, MTCMOS, Adiabatic Logic Circuits).

To design and perform the transient analysis and DC analysis (VTC) of Resistive load inverter.

To design and perform transient Analysis and DC Analysis (VTC) of CMOS inverter.

To design and simulate the NAND and NOR Gate using Static CMOS logic.

To design and simulate the XOR and XNOR using pseudo techniques.

To design and simulate the Half adder and Full adder using Dynamic CMOS logic.

To design and simulate the given boolean expression using Domino CMOS logic.

To design and simulate the MUX using the Transmission Gate.

To design and simulate the SR and JK Flip Flop.

To design and Simulate Master-slave Flip Flop using CMOS logic.

To design and simulate D Flip flop using CMOS Logic.

To design and simulate the various logic circuits using MTCMOS and VTCMOS techniques.

Layout design of CMOS inverter.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | To get familiar with emerging VLSI Design and basic theory of MOStransistors. | K2 |
| C02 | To understand the various characteristics used in the design of CMOSlogic circuits. | K2 |
| C03 | To implementation of logic gates using Digital CMOS circuits. | K3 |
| C04 | Develop basic understanding to design basic Analog CMOS circuits. | K3 |
| C05 | Analysis of the low power techniques for CMOS Circuits. | K4 |

Kang, S. M., Leblebici, Y., and Kim, C., “CMOS Digital Integrated Circuits: Analysis and Design”, 4th Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2016.

Rabaey, J. M., Chandrakasan, A., and Nikolic, B., “Digital Integrated Circuits: A Design Perspective”, 2nd edition, Pearson Education, 2016.

Weste, Neil HE, David Harris, “CMOS VLSI design: a circuits and systems perspective”, 3rd edition, Pearson Education India, 2006.

Ajit. Pal, “Low-power VLSI circuits and systems”, First Edition, Springer, 2014.

heading_path: Unit IV: Financing and Business Stability
content:
| Course Code | ICAE302 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Entrepreneurship and Start-ups |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-0-3 |
| Course Type | AE |

• To impart basic entrepreneurial skills and understanding to run a business efficiently and effectively.

• To develop and strengthen motivation and leadership skills in students.

• To make them understand the classification of MSMEs in India and exposing to new business trends for startups.

• To provide the understanding for various financial resources and sustaining the business enterprise.

• To update students with various govt. schemes for the support of sick units and strategies for business growth.

Concept of Entrepreneurship, Entrepreneurial skills, Characteristics of an Entrepreneur, Types of Entrepreneurs, Difference between Entrepreneur and Intrapreneur, Barriers to Entrepreneurship, Risks to an Entrepreneur. Process in Entrepreneurship, Macroeconomic environment, Influence of macroeconomic conditions on Entrepreneurship.

Psychology theories of entrepreneurship, McClelland’s Theory of motivation, Rotter’s Locus of Control Theory, Action Regulation Theory, Stress Management, Leading mission-driven organizations, Developing Mission, Vision, and Goals statements of the organizations, Developing competitive advantage, Generic competitive strategy, Building Motivated Team. Entrepreneurship Development Programs, Need, Objectives.

MSME – Definition, Classification, Characteristics, Role and Importance of MSMEs in Indian Economy, Ownership Structures, Types of new age business, FinTech, EdTech, Healthcare, AgriTech, Robotics, and Digital Transformation, Emerging markets for EntrepreneursCybersecurity and cloud computing, Tax management, Real Estate, supply chain and logistics. Formulation of Project report, Need, Objectives, and Components of a Project Report, TechnoEconomic, Market, and Financial Feasibility Assessment of a project.

Methods of Financing to Startups, Funding Strategies, Different types of Funding, Sources of

Finance, Term Loans, Capital Structure, Financial Institution, Management of working Capital, Scaling up and stabilization of a business, strategies for scaling business. Data Analytics to advantage, Advantages of Data Analytics.

Sickness in small Business, Concept, Magnitude, Causes and Consequences, Corrective Measures, Business Incubators, Government Policy for Small Scale Enterprises, Growth Strategies in small industry, Expansion, Diversification, Joint Venture, Merger and Sub Contracting.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Understand the entrepreneurial mind-set and what it takes to createvalue. | K2 |
| C02 | Develop motivation and leadership to start one's own business. | K3 |
| C03 | Analyse the business enterprises in order to identify business opportu-nities in trending new age businesses. | K4 |
| C04 | Learn to secure financial backing and sustain business growth. | K1 |
| C05 | Evaluates the effectiveness of different entrepreneurial strategies. | K5 |

Khanka. S.S., “Entrepreneurial Development” S.Chand & Co. Ltd.,Ram Nagar, New Delhi, 2013.

Donald F Kuratko, “Entrepreneurship – Theory, Process and Practice”, 9th Edition, Cengage Learning 2014.

“Innovation and Entrepreneurship” by Peter F. Drucker,2006

“The Lean Startup: How Today’s Entrepreneurs Use Continuous Innovation to Create Radically Successful Businesses” by Eric Ries,2011

“Small Business Management: Launching and Growing Entrepreneurial Ventures” by Justin G. Longenecker, J. William Petty, and Leslie E. Palich,2017

“Entrepreneurship Development and Small Business Enterprises” by Poornima M. Charantimath, 978-9353066260, 2018

“Entrepreneurship and Startup” by Institute of Cost Accountants of India, Kolkata,2018

“Disciplined Entrepreneurship: 24 Steps to a Successful Startup” by Bill Aulet,2013

| Course Code | ICOC302 |

| Course'Title | Optional Online Course- II* |

• To learn the state-of-art methods for the project domain.
• To survey research problems and derive methodologies to solve the problem.
• To analyze state-of-the-art techniques to solve real world problems.
• To demonstrate and implement the proposed solution.

In this course, the student is expected to work on a project to solve a real-world problem un- der the supervision of the faculty member. The project work include detailed literature survey,problem formulation, experimentation plan and its implementation in a form of working proto- type.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |

| C04 | Analyze and compare the available solutions. | K4 |
| C05 | Plan, propose, and implement the proposed solution. | K6 |

| Course Code | ICOC402 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Optional Online Course- IV* |
