| Course Type | OC |

The Students can opt for Optional Online Course along with their normal courses. The students can choose online courses from NPTEL/SWAYAM/MOOCs. In Optional course the credit will not be counted for the calculation of the final CGPA but the credit will appear in the Grade card and transcript.

| Course Code | ECSE301 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Data Communication and Networks |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To provide the fundamental concepts of computer networks, reference models and its functionalities.

• To explore the different types of signalling schemes and channel access techniques in physical layer.

• To identify the key design issues of data link and network layer protocols.

• To evaluate the network performance using various services provided by transport and application layers.

Unit I: Introduction to Computer Networks

Network, Component and Categories, Topologies, Transmission Media, Reference Models: ISO/OSI Model and TCP/IP Model.

Digital and Analog Signals, Periodic Analog Signals, Transmission Impairments, Digital data transmission techniques, Analog data transmission techniques, Multiplexing and Spread Spectrum.

Error Detection and Correction, Parity, LRC-CRC, Hamming Code, Flow Control and Error Control, Stop and wait, ARQ, Sliding window, HDLC, Multiple Access Protocols, IEEE 802.3 Ethernet.

Packet Switching and Datagram approach, IP addressing methods, Subnetting, Routing, Distance Vector Routing, Link State Routing, Broadcast and Multicast Routing.

Transport Services, UDP, TCP, Congestion Control, Quality of Services (QOS), Application Layer: Domain Name Space (DNS), Electronic Mail.

Study of different typed of Networks Cable and Practically Implement the cross-wired cable and straight through cable using clamping tool.

Install and Configure Wired and Wireless NIC and transfer files between systems in LAN and Wireless LAN.

Install and configure Network Devices: HUB, Switch and Routers.

Connect the Computers in Local Area Network.

Configure Host IP, Subnet Mask and Default Gateway in a System in LAN (TCP/IP Configuration).

Establish Peer to Peer network connection using two systems using Switch and Router in a LAN.

Configure Internet connection and use IPCONFIG, PING / Tracer and Net stat utilities to debug the network issues.

Transfer files between systems in LAN using FTP Configuration, install Print server in a LAN and share the printer in a network.

Router Configuration Using Packet Tracer.

Connection oriented Client server applications with TCP Assignment.

Connectionless Client server applications with UDP Assignment.

Study of Socket Programming and Client – Server Model.

Configure a Network Topology using packet tracer software.

Configure a Network using Distance Vector Routing Protocol.

Configure a Network using Link State Vector Routing Protocol.

To get the MAC or Physical address of the system using Address Resolution Protocol.

Simulate the Implementing Routing Protocols using border gateway protocol (BGP) .

Simulate the OPEN SHORTEST PATH FIRST routing protocol based on the cost assigned to the path

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Infer the layered protocol approach in computer networking. | K2 |
| C02 | Explain and apply the fundamentals of signal processing in the physical layer of the computer networking. | K3 |
| C03 | Make use of various error detection and correction services provided bythe data link layer. | K3 |
| C04 | Analyze the various addressing and routing services provided by the network layer and design network layer protocols. | K4 |
| C05 | Infer and apply various services provided by the transport and the ap-plication layer. | K3 |

Foruzan, B. A., “Data Communication and Networking”, 5th Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Tanenbaum, A. S. and Wetherall, D. J., “Computer Networks”, 5th Edition, Pearson Education, 2013. .

Stallings, W., “Data and Computer Communication”, 10th Edition, Pearson Education, 2017.

heading_path: Unit IV: AVR on-chip peripherals and its programming
content:
| Course Code | ECSE302 |
| --- | --- |
| Course'Title | Embedded Systems |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To learn about the characteristics and challenges of embedded systems.

• To learn about the typical AVR ATmega32 Microcontroller.

• To learn the assembly language programs for AVR Microcontroller.

• To understand the architecture and functionalities of AVR on-chip peripherals.

• To Interface I/O peripheral devices with AVR microcontroller to develop the embedded system.

History of embedded system, Embedded Systems vs General computing systems, Classification of embedded system, Major application areas, Characteristics of embedded system, Constraints, Characteristics and Quality Attributes of Embedded Systems. Introduction to RISC/CISC-based machines. Introduction to 8051 microcontroller.

AVR Microcontroller architecture: Registers, AVR status register, Memory Space, ATmega32 pin-configuration & function of each pin, Addressing mode and instruction set of AVR microcontroller, Data transfer, Arithmetic, Logic and Compare, Rotate and Shift, Branch and Call instructions, Bit manipulation instructions.

AVR data types and assembler directives, AVR assembly language programs, AVR I/O Port Programming, Time delay loop, BCD, ASCII conversion Program, Look-up table, Bit addressability, MACROs, Pros and cons of C and assembly language programming, Data types, Intex Hex file format, Simple C programs for general purpose I/O and bit addressability.

General purpose I/O Ports, Timers, Interrupts, serial port, Serial port Interfacing protocols, SPI, I2C, UART. Assembly and C Language programming for peripherals.

LCD and GLCD interfacing, Keyboard Interfacing, TFT interfacing, ADC, DAC and sensor interfacing, Relay, Opto-isolator and Stepper Motor Interfacing, Industrial servo interfacing, Input capture and Wave Generator, PWM programming and DC motor control, SPI protocol and Display interfacing, I2C Protocol and RTC interfacing. Assembly and C Programming.

Understand Arduino open source hardware and programming environment and write program to blink LED using Arduino instructions, C language & Assembly language.

Interface Digital/Analog input output interfacing module with Arduino board and write programs related to I/O module.

Generate PWM waveform and change intensity of LED connected with Arduino board.

Write and execute Arduino program for serial communication. Transmit temperature value through serial communication and store it in spreadsheet or text file.

Write and execute Arduino program to display message and numbers on LCD, GLCD and TFT.

Write and execute Arduino program to read analog value. Sense temperature using LM35 sensor and display temperature value on LCD.

Write assembly language programs for ATMega32 Microcontroller and simulate using ATMEL Studio.

Understand hardware of ATMega32 Kit. Write program to flash LEDs, read status of switches, Display count values on seven segment display. Upload programs in the kit one by one and execute.

Write program to read switch status and display it on LCD. Write program in Assembly as well as C language.

Write program to rotate stepper motor in half-step and full-step mode in Assembly as well as C language. Simulate program using PROTEUS software.

Write program to rotate DC motor in clockwise and anti-clockwise direction in Assembly as well as C language. Simulate program using PROTEUS software.

Observe waveforms of I2C and SPI communication and understand I2C and SPI protocol.

Write Arduino program to receive IR Signal from IR remote and operate Electrical device based on switch pressed.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Infer the overallandscape and characteristics of embedded systems. | K2 |
| C02 | Analyze the architecture, pin configuration, addressing modes,and in- struction set of the AVR microcontroller, including ATmega32. | K3 |
| C03 | Develop AVR assembly and C programs using data types,assemblerdirectives, and Intel HEX file format, and implement I/O port program-ming, bit addressability, time delays,and look-up tables to solve practi-cal embedded system tasks. | K4 |
| C04 | Design and implement efficient assembly and C programs to configureand utilize AVR on-chip Peripherals. | K6 |
| CO5 | Develop assembly and C programs for device interfacing,including dis-plays, sensors, motors,and communication protocols, to design and im-plement practical embedded system applications. | K5 |

Muhammad Ali Mazidi, Sarmad Naimi and Sepehr Naimi,”The AVR Microcontroller and Embedded Systems”, Using Assembly and C, Pearson Education, 1st Edition,2012.

Dhananjay Gadre, “Programming and Customizing the AVR Microcontroller”, TMH, 1st Edition, 2001.

Muhammad Ali Mazidi, Janice Gillispie Mazidi and Rolin D. McKinlay,“The 8051 Micro controllers & Embedded Systems Using Assembly and C” 2nd Indian reprint, Pearson education, 2005.

William Hohl, “ARM Assembly Language: Fundamentals and Techniques” CRC Press, 2009.

Tammy Noergaard, “Embedded Systems Architecture: A Comprehensive Guide for Engineers and Programmers (Embedded Technology)” Elsevier, Newnes.

| Course Code | ECSE303 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Digital Design and Synthesis |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To Understand the language constructs and programming fundamentals of Verilog HDL.

• To Construct circuits in Gate level modeling style using Verilog HDL

• To Construct circuits in Data flow modeling style using Verilog HDL

• To Construct circuits in behavioral modeling style using Verilog HDL.

• To Analyze and Verify the functionality of digital circuits/systems using test benches.

Verilog as HDL, Levels of Design Description, Concurrency, Program structure, Top-down and Bottomup design methodology, differences between modules and module instances, parts of a simulation, design block, stimulus block, Verilog Data types and Operators, system tasks, compiler directives.

Modelling using basic Verilog gate Primitives, Description of and/or and buf/not type gates, rise, fall and turn-off delays, min, max, and typical delays, Design of Decoders, Multiplexers, Flip-flops, Registers & Counters in Gate-level Modeling.

Continuous assignments, Delay specification, expressions, operators, Design of Decoders, Multiplexers, Flip-flops, Registers & Counters in dataflow model.

User- Defined Primitives (UDP, System tasks, functions, and compiler directives, Creating test benches for Verilog HDL design verification. Hierarchical design and reusable modules, Parameterized Modules and Macros, Designing Memories and Arithmetic circuits in Verilog HDL, Designing Finite State Machines with Mealy and Moore Models, Verification process and types of simulation, Debugging and error tracing in Verilog HDL design.

Test Bench - Combinational Circuits Testing, Sequential Circuits Testing, Test Bench Techniques, Design Verification, Assertion Verification.

Write Verilog code to realize all the logic gates

Write a Verilog program for the following combinational designs a. 2 to 4 decoder b. 8 to 3 (encoder without priority & with priority) c. 8 to 1 multiplexer. d. 4-bit binary to gray converter

Write Verilog code to describe the functions of a Full Adder using three modeling styles.

Write Verilog code for Code Converter: BCD to Excess-3 code converter, gray code to binary converter.

Develop the Verilog code for the following flip-flops, SR, D, JK and T.

Design a 4-bit binary, BCD counters (Synchronous reset and Asynchronous reset) and “any sequence” counters, using Verilog code.

Write Verilog code for counter with given input clock and check whether it works as clock divider performing division of clock by 2, 4, 8 and 16. Verify the functionality of the code.

Write a Verilog code to design a clock divider circuit that generates 1/2, 1/3rd and 1/4thclock from a given input clock. Port the design to FPGA and validate the functionality through oscilloscope.

Interface a DC motor to FPGA and write Verilog code to change its speed and direction.

Flip-Flop: assemble, test and investigate operation of S-R, D & J-K flip-flops.

Write Verilog code using FSM to simulate elevator operation.

Write Verilog code to convert an analog input of a sensor to digital form and to display the same on a suitable display like set of simple LEDs, 7-segment display digits or LCD display. Design of Combinational circuits using the Verilog HDL module.

Write HDL code to display messages on an alpha numeric LCD display.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Learn Verilog HDL and apply it for simple and complex designs. | K2 |
| C02 | Demonstrate knowledge on HDL design flow, digital circuits design,switch de-bouncing, metastability | K3 |
| C03 | Choose the suitable abstraction level for a particular digital design. | K3 |
| C04 | Construct Combinational and sequential circuits in different modelling styles using Verilog | K4 |
| C05 | Analyse and Verify the functionality of digital circuits/systems usingtest benches | K2 |

Samir Palnitkar, ”Verilog HDL: A Guide to Digital Design and Synthesis”, Pearson Education, Second Edition.

Michael D. Ciletti, ”Advanced Digital Design with the Verilog HDL” Pearson (Prentice Hall), Second edition.

Stephen Brown and Zvonko Vranesic - Fundamentals of Digital Logic with Verilog, 2nd Edition, TMH,

Z Navabi - Verilog Digital System Design, 2nd Edition, McGraw Hill, 2005.

| CourseCode | ECSE304 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Fiber Optic Communication |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To know the principles of Fiber optic communication.
• To learn the concepts and types of optical sources.
• To study the various types of optical detectors and their applications.
• To learn the principle of optical amplification for different types of optical amplifiers.
• To understand the concepts of optical switching and networks.

Optical evolution, advantages of optical communication, its representations, Optical waveguides, basic optical laws, acceptance angle, numerical aperture Skew rays, Rays and modes, step-index, graded-index fibers, phase and group velocities, Signal degradation in optical fibers, attenuation units, absorption, scattering dispersions.

Optical source properties, finding the energy from the voltage, finding the frequency from the wavelength of light, operating wavelength of optical sources, semiconductor light-emitting diodes and laser diodes, semiconductor material and device operating principles, light-emitting diodes, surface-emitting LEDS, edge-emitting LEDS, super luminescent diodes, laser diodes, comparison of LED and ILD. Fiber optic transmitters, basic optical transmitters, direct versus external modulation, fiber optic transmitter applications, digital applications, analog applications.

Light detectors, Role of an optical detector, Detector characteristics: Responsivity, Noise Equivalent Power, Detectivity, Quantum efficiency, Detector response time, Linearity, Spectral response, Noise considerations: Johnson noise, Shot noise, 1/f noise, Photon noise, The PN junction photo diode - PIN photodetector - Avalanche photo diode construction characteristics and properties, APD Specifications, Applications of APD - comparison of performance noise sources - simple model of photo receiver - Its equivalent for circulation of noise SNR, Optical Receivers.

Basic Concepts, Gain Spectrum and Bandwidth, Gain Saturation, Amplifier Noise, Amplifier Applications, Semiconductor Optical Amplifiers, Raman Amplifiers, Erbium-Doped Fiber

Amplifiers, System Applications - Optical Pre-amplification, Noise Accumulation in LongHaul Systems, ASE-Induced Timing Jitter, Accumulated Dispersive and Nonlinear Effects, WDM-Related Impairments.

Transport Networks, Applications, Requirements, Architectures, Technologies, and Solutions, Introduction to Optical Access Networks, Optical TDM, subscriber multiplexing (SCM), WDM and Hybrid multiplexing methods.

Handling of Fibers.

Index profiles of Optical Fibers

Characteristics of LED.

Characteristics of Laser Diode.

Characteristics of Photo Detector.

Characteristics of APD

Measurement of Numerical Aperture.

Measurement of Attenuation.

Measurement of Bending Loss

Fiber Dispersion Measurement.

Study of BER and Q-Factor.

Characteristics of WDM Link.

Analog and voice communication through optical link.

Simulation & BER calculation using OPTSIM.

Responsivity of detector.

EDFA Design for D-WDM using OPTSIM.

Characteristics of AWGN & BSC channel.

BPSK Modulator and Demodulation.

Convolutional encoder & decoder.

Time Division Multiplexing.

Analog communication through optical link.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the basic principle and various types of transmission impair-ments of Fiber-optic communication. | K2 |
| C02 | Make use of different types of optical sources in various applications. | K3 |
| C03 | Apply the concepts of optical detection techniques for extracting theoriginal signal. | K3 |
| C04 | Develop amplifed signals with various types of optical amplifiers. | K3 |
| C05 | Infer the knowledge about WDM and optical networks for optical linkdesign. | K4 |

Senior, J, M., “Optical Fiber Communications: Principles and Practice”, 3rd edition, Pearson Education, 2010.

Keiser, G., “Optical Fiber Communications”, 5th edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Agrawal, G. P., “Fiber Optic Communication Systems”, 5th edition, Wiley, 2021.

Liu, M. M. K., “Principles and Applications of Optical Communications”, 1st edition, McGraw Hill, 2010.

heading_path: Unit V: Advanced Topics in Neural Networks
content:
| Course Code | ECSE305 |
| --- | --- |
| Course Title | Artificial Neural Networks |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To Stay updated with the latest research and advancements in the field of neural networks

• To Understand the basic concepts and architecture of artificial neural networks.

• To Learn different training algorithms and their applications.

• To Explore various types of neural networks including feedforward, convolutional, and recurrent networks.

• To Apply neural networks to solve practical problems.

History and evolution of neural networks, Biological inspiration, Basic concepts and terminology, Neuron model: McCulloch-Pitts neuron, Types of activation functions, Introduction to perceptron and multilayer perceptron (MLP)

Hebbian Learning Rule, Perceptron Learning Rule,Delta Learning Rule (Widrow-Hoff Rule), Competitive Learning Rule, General Architecture and Building Blocks of Pattern Classification Networks, Principle of Linear Separability, ,Hebb Net: Algorithm and Applications, Perceptron: Architecture, Algorithm, Applications, and Convergence Theorem, Adaline: Architecture, Algorithm, and Applications, Madaline: Architecture, MRI and MRII Algorithms.

Hebb Rule and Delta Rule for Pattern Association, Hetero-associative Memory Networks, Auto-associative Memory Networks, Hopfield Networks, Bidirectional Associative Memory Networks

Feedforward neural networks, Convolutional neural networks: Architecture and layers, convolution, pooling, fully connected, Applications in image processing, Recurrent neural networks (RNNs), Long short-term memory (LSTM), Gated recurrent units (GRUs), Applications in sequential data.

Transfer learning, Generative adversarial networks (GANs), Autoencoders and variational autoencoders (VAEs), Attention mechanisms and transformers, Reinforcement learning with neural networks.

Implement a single McCulloch-Pitts neuron and demonstrate its ability to perform basic logical operations (AND, OR, NOT).

Implement the Perceptron learning algorithm and train it on a linearly separable dataset.

Implement the Adaline model using gradient descent and compare its performance with the Perceptron.

Implement a simple MLP for classification tasks using backpropagation.

Implement Various Activation Functions.

Implement Multilayer Feedforward Network.

Develop a multilayer perceptron for solving non-linearly separable problems.

Implement a Hopfield network and demonstrate its ability to retrieve stored patterns.

Implement a simple GAN and generate new data samples from the learned distribution..

Implement a recurrent neural network (RNN) or LSTM for time series forecasting.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Understand Fundamental Concepts of Neural Networks | K2 |
| C02 | Designing and Implementing Neural Networks | K2 |
| C03 | Applying Neural Networks to Real-World Problems | K6 |
| C04 | Analyzing and Evaluating Neural Network Performance | K4 |
| C05 | Exploring Advanced Topics and Emerging Trends | K6 |

Goodfellow, I., Bengio, Y., and Courville, A., “Deep Learning”, MIT Press, 2020.

Aggarwal, C. C., “Neural Networks and Deep Learning: A Textbook”, Springer, 2018.

Haykin, S., “Neural Networks and Learning Machines”, 3rd Edition, Pearson Education, 2018.

Ng, A., “Machine Learning Yearning”, DeepLearning.AI, 2018.

| CourseCode | ECSE306 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Digital Image Processing |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To understand and explore the basics of Digital Image Processing.

• To understand concepts of intensity transformations and filtering in spatial domain.

• To implement frequency domain filters for image processing applications.

• To familiarize with the concepts of colour image processing.

• To visualize and implement basic computer vision algorithms.

Elements of visual perception, Digital Image fundamentals: Image sensing and acquisition, Image sampling and quantization, Image Processing Toolbox in MATLAB: Digital Image Representation, Reading, Displaying and Writing images, Data Classes, Image Types, Converting between data classes and image types, array indexing, Some important standard arrays.

Intensity Transformations Functions, Histogram Processing, Fundamentals of Spatial Filtering, Smoothening Spatial Filters, Sharpening Spatial Filters, Design of various Spatial Filters from Lowpass Filters, Spatial Enhancement Methods.

Sampling and the Fourier Transform of Sampled Functions, The Discrete Fourier Transform, Properties of the 2-D DFT and IDFT, Filtering in the Frequency Domain, Image Smoothing Using Lowpass Frequency Domain Filters, Image Sharpening Using Highpass Filters, Selective Filtering.

Image Transforms: DCT, DWT, Radon Transforms; Colour Image Processing: Color Models, Pseudocolor Image Processing, Full-Color Image Processing, Color Transformations, Color Image Smoothing and Sharpening, Noise in Color Images.

Point, Line, and Edge Detection, Thresholding, Segmentation by Region Growing and by Region Splitting and Merging, Region Segmentation Using Clustering and Superpixels, Region Segmentation Using Graph Cuts, Principal Components as Feature Descriptors, Whole-Image Features, Scale-Invariant Feature Transform (SIFT).

Convert RGB based images into Gray Scale Images using MATLAB.

Generate RGB components of the image using MATLAB.

Implement the Histogram Equalization using MATLAB.

Implement the design techniques of Non-linear Filtering using MATLAB.

Detect the Edges using Operators in MATLAB.

Implement Discrete Fourier Transform using MATLAB.

Implement Discrete Cosine Transform using MATLAB.

Implementing techniques of Filtering in frequency domain

Implement low pass filtering technique in frequency domain using MATLAB.

Implement high pass filtering technique in frequency domain using MATLAB.

Developing, creating and display of colour images.

Implement conversion between colour spaces.

Implement Image Segmentation using watershed transform using MATLAB.

Implement PCA algorithm on images.

Implement SIFT algorithm on images to extract the features.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 3 0 = 7 0$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Demonstrate understanding of the fundamentals of digital image pro-cessing. | K2 |
| C02 | Develop understanding and underlying techniques of Intensity transfor-mations and filtering. | K3 |
| C03 | Develop understanding of frequency domain processing techniques. | K3 |
| C04 | Perform the colour image processing by applying colour transforma- tions and use colour information in image segmentation | K3 |
| C05 | Execute image segmentation and feature extraction | K3 |

Gonzalez, Rafael C. Digital image processing. Pearson education India, 2009.

Digital Image Processing Using MATLAB by Rafael C. Gonzalez, Richard E. Woods, and Steven L. Eddins

Fundamentals of Digital Image Processing by Anil K. Jain

Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications by Richard Szeliski

Image Processing, Analysis, and Machine Vision by Milan Sonka, Vaclav Hlavac, and Roger Boyle.

Pattern Recognition and Image Analysis by Earl Gose, Richard Johnsonbaugh, and Steve Jost

| CourseCode | ECSE401 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Wireless Communication |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To enable students to acquire in-depth knowledge in the field of wireless communication.

• To familiarize with state-of-the-art standards used in wireless cellular systems.

• To develop students to critically analyze the problems in the field of wireless communication technology and find optimal solution.

• To study the various multiple access techniques.

• To learn the different protocols for GSM and CDMA techniques

Evolution of mobile communications, Concept of frequency reuse, Channel Assignment Strategies, Channel and co- channel interference reduction factor, S/I ratio consideration and calculation for Minimum Co-channel and adjacent interference, Handoff strategies, Trunking and Grade of Service, Improving Coverage & Capacity in Cellular System-cell splitting, Cell sectoring, Repeaters, Micro cell zone concept.

Free Space Propagation model, Reflection, Ground reflection model, Diffraction, Scattering, Link budget design, Max. Distance Coverage formula, Empirical formula for path loss, Indoor and outdoor propagation models, Small scale multipath propagation, Impulse model for multipath channel, Small scale multipath measurements, Parameters of mobile multipath channels, Types of small scale fading, Rayleigh and Ricean distribution, Statistical models for multipath fading channels and diversity techniques in brief.

Introduction, Frequency Division Multiple Access, Time Division Multiple Access, Spread Spectrum Multiple Access, Spread Division Multiple Access, Packer Radio, Carrier Sense Multiple Access Protocols, Capacity of Cellular Systems.

Introduction to CDMA, Fundamentals of CDMA Codes, Correlation Properties of Random CDMA Spreading Sequences, Spread-Spectrum Principles, Direct-Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS), DSSS System Model, RAKE Receivers, Frequency-Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS).

Data Transmission Using Multiple Carriers, Multicarrier Modulation with Overlapping Sub channels, Discrete Implementation of Multicarrier Modulation, The Cyclic Prefix, OFDM, Matrix Representation of OFDM, Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR), Frequency and Timing Offset, SC-FDMA, Subcarrier Mapping in SC-FDMA.

Introduction to NI LabVIEW and USRP hardware.

M-ary QAM Modulation and Detection with BER performance.

Pulse Shaping and Matched Filtering.

Channel Estimation & Equalization.

Code Division Multiple access

Spread Spectrum – DSSS modulation and Detection

Synchronization- Frame Detection & Frequency Offset Correction.

Simulation of OFDM Modulation & Demodulation.

Frequency Domain Equalization.

Implementation of OFDM on USRP.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 8 = 6 8$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the cellular system design and technical challenges. | K2 |
| C02 | Analyze the mobile radio propagation, fading, diversity concepts andthe channel modeling. | K2 |
| C03 | Analyze the design parameters, link design, smart antenna, beam form-ing and MIMO systems. | K3 |
| C04 | Analyze Multiuser Systems, CDMA, WCDMA network planning andSpread spectrum techniques. | K3 |
| C05 | Analyze Multicarrier Systems, OFDM， Synchronization, and SC-FDMA techniques. | K3 |

Rappaport, T. S., “Wireless Communication: Principles and Practice”, 2nd Edition, Pearson, 2010..

Aditya K J, “Principles of Modern Wireless Communication Systems Theory and Practice”, McGraw Hill Education, 2016.

Goldsmith, “Wireless Communications”, Cambridge university press, 2005.

Lee, W. C. Y., “Mobile Communication Engineering: Theory and Applications”, 2nd Edition, McGraw Hill Education, 2017.

Feher, K., “Wireless Digital Communications: Modulation and Spread Spectrum Applications”, 1st Edition, Prentice Hall India, 1995.

| Course Code | ECSE402 |
| --- | --- |
| Course Title | Antenna and Wave Propagation |
| LTPC | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | SE |

• To learn basic concepts radiation from antenna element.

• To impart knowledge on principle of pattern multiplication in antenna arrays.

• To study different types of aperture and slot antennas.

• To study various special antennas and their polarization characteristics.

• To learn different wave propagation mechanisms and their applications.

Introduction to antennas, Definition of antenna parameters, Gain, Directivity, Effective aperture, Radiation Resistance, Band width, Beam width, Input Impedance. Matching, Baluns, Polarization mismatch, Antenna noise temperature, Radiation from oscillating dipole, Half wave dipole, Folded dipole, Yagi array.

N element linear array, Pattern multiplication, Broadside and End fire array, Concept of Phased arrays, Adaptive array, Basic principle of antenna Synthesis-Binomial array.

Radiation from rectangular apertures, Uniform and Tapered aperture, Horn antenna, Reflector antenna, Aperture blockage, Feeding structures, Slot antennas, Microstrip antennas, Radiation mechanism, Application, Numerical tool for antenna analysis.

Principle of frequency independent antennas, Spiral antenna, Helical antenna, Log periodic. Modern antennas- Reconfigurable antenna, Active-antenna, Dielectric antennas, Electronic band gap structure and applications, Antenna Measurements-Test Ranges, Measurement of Gain, Radiation pattern, Polarization, VSWR.

Propagation in free space. Propagation around the earth, surface wave-propagation, structure of the ionosphere, propagation of plane waves in ionized medium, Determination of critical frequency, MUF, Fading, tropospheric propagation, Super refraction.

Introduction to Microwave CST studio suite.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Wire antennas.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Half-Wavelength dipole antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a folded dipole antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Yagi antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Horn antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Spiral antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a Helical antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a microstrip patch antenna.

Designing, simulation, and analysis of a microstrip patch antenna array.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain fundamentals of radiation and mechanism of radiation from os-cillating dipole. | K2 |
| C02 | Develop different types of antenna arrays and study their radiation pat-tern. | K3 |
| C03 | Apply numerical tools and techniques for analysis of radiation fromdifferent aperture and slot antennas. | K3 |
| C04 | Categorize different types of antennas and examine their radiation char-acteristics. | K4 |
| C05 | Assess and compare different mechanisms for wave propagation in free space. | K5 |

Balanis, C. A., “Antenna Theory: Analysis and Design”, 4th Edition, Wiley, 2016.

Collin, R. E., “Antennas and Radiowave Propagation”, 4th Edition, McGraw-Hill, 1985.

Krauss, J. D., “Antennas for All Applications”, 3rd Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2005.

| Course Code | SCMS301 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Artificial Intelligence |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-0-3 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn the basics of Artificial Intelligence.
• To be able to mathematically represent knowledge.
• To learn the methods of solving problems in Artificial Intelligence.
• To learn various game playing and planning techniques.
• To learn semantic analysis and its application in NLP.

Control strategies, Search strategies, Production system characteristics, Specialized production system, Problem-solving methods, Problem graphs, Matching, Indexing, and Heuristic functions, Hill Climbing, Depth-first and Breadth-first, satisfaction, Related algorithms, Measure of performance and analysis of search algorithms.

Knowledge representation, Knowledge representation using Predicate logic, Introduction to predicate calculus, Resolution, Use of predicate calculus, Knowledge representation using other Logic-Structured representation of knowledge.

Production-based system, Frame-based system. Inference: Backward chaining, forward chaining, Rule value approach, Fuzzy reasoning, Certainty factors, Bayesian Theory, Bayesian Network, Dempster-Shafer theory.

Overview, Min-Max search procedure, Alpha-beta cut-offs, Iterative Deepening, Components of planning system, goal stack planning, non-linear planning, hierarchal planning and other planning techniques, reactive systems.

Introduction to Understanding, Understanding as constraint satisfaction, Introduction to NLP, Syntactic and Semantic analysis, Statistical NLP, and Spell Checking.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Learn the basic concepts of artificial intelligence. | K2 |
| C02 | Learn the knowledge using predicate calculus. | K2 |
| C03 | Identify problems that are amenably solved by AI methods. | K3 |
| C04 | Apply various game-playing techniques in artificial intelligence. | K3 |
| C05 | Understand semantic information in NLP applications. | K3 |

Russell, Norvig ”Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach”, Fourth Edition, Pearson Education, 2022.

Rich, Elaine, Kevin Knight, and Shivashankar B. Nair. “Artificial intelligence” . (2010).

Winston, Patrick Henry. “Artificial intelligence”. Addison-Wesley Longman Publishing Co., Inc., 1992.

Kheemani, Deepak, “A First Course in Artificial Intelligence”, McGraw Hill Education, First Edition, 2017.

Floridi L. “The ethics of artificial intelligence: Principles, challenges, and opportunities”,2023.

| CourseCode | SEMS301 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | VLSI Technology |
| Number : of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-0-3 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn about clean room and safety requirements for VLSI Technology.

• To learn different fabrication and characterization techniques.

• To learn and understand Oxidation and Lithography.

• To learn and understand Chemical Vapour Deposition techniques

• To learn and understand basic concepts of Nano-science and Nanotechnology.

Unit I: Environment for VLSI Technology

Clean room and safety requirements. Wafer cleaning processes and wet chemical etching techniques.

Solid State diffusion modeling and technology; Ion Implantation modeling, technology and damage annealing; characterization of Impurity profiles.

Kinetics of Silicon dioxide growth both for thick, thin and ultrathin films. Oxidation Technologies in VLSI and ULSI; Characterization of oxide films; High k and low k dielectrics for ULSI. Photolithography, E-beam lithography and newer lithography techniques for VLSI/ULSI; Mask generation.

CVD techniques for deposition of polysilicon, silicon dioxide, silicon nitride and metal films;
Epitaxial growth of silicon; modeling and technology.

Basic principles of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, Background of nanotechnology, types of nano-technology and nano-machines, top down and bottom up techniques, atomic manipulationnanodots, semi-conductor quantum dots, self-assembly monolayers, Simple details of characterization tools- SEM, TEM, STM, AFM.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Understand material processing techniques and Pattern Transfer process | K2 |
| C02 | Evaluate different fabrication and characterization techniques | K3 |
| C03 | Demonstrates the concept behind thin film deposition, and characteri- zation techniques | K3 |
| C04 | Compare metal contact formation, interconnect, bonding and packaging | K3 |
| C05 | Infer the overall landscape and characteristics of nanoscience and nan-otechnology | K2 |

S. M. Sze (Ed), VLSI Technology, 2nd Edition, McGraw-Hill, 2017.

Datta, S., “Lessons from Nanoelectronics: A New Perspective on Transport”, 2nd edition, World Scientific, 2018.

C.Y. Chang and S.M. Sze (Ed), ULSI Technology, McGraw-Hill Companies Inc.

S. K. Gandhi, VLSI fabrication Principles, John Wiley Inc.

| Course Code | SCMS302 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Soft Computing |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To understand the concepts of soft computing techniques.
• To understand the concepts of evolutionary computation.
• To impart adequate knowledge about Neural Networks.
• To understand the general principles of Fuzzy Logic Controllers.
• To apply soft computing algorithms for solving complex problems.

Unit I: Introduction To Soft Computing

Soft computing vs. Hard computing, Applications of soft Computing, Various types of Soft Computing techniques, Neuron Nerve structure and Synapse, McCulloch Pitts neuron model, Perceptron model, Neural network Architecture, Applications

Historical Development of EC, Genetic programming- Evolutionary Strategies, features of Evolutionary computation, Advantages and Applications of Evolutionary Computation, Basic concept of Genetic algorithm, Genetic Operators, Comparison of Genetic Algorithm with Other Optimization Techniques, Advantages, Applications and Limitations of Genetic Algorithm.

Types of Neural Network, Advantages and Drawbacks, Applications of Single layer and multilayer feed forward networks, back propagation learning methods, effect of learning rule coefficient.

Fuzzy Logic, Applications, Fuzzy set and classical set, membership functions, fuzzy terminologies: Linguistic terms, Support, core, normality, cross over, fuzzy singleton, alpha cut, strong alpha cut, fuzzy set operations (Union, Intersection, Complement, Algebraic product, Algebraic sum, Algebraic Difference, Multiplication of fuzzy sets by a crisp number, Power of Fuzzy Set, Bounded Sum, Bounded Difference, Cartesian Product, Equal Fuzzy Sets

Particle Swarm Optimization, Applications, Fuzzy control Systems, Applications, Fuzzy controller, Fuzzy Inference System, Mamdani Approach, Defuzzification; Center of sum method,

Advantages, Drawbacks, Applications, Clustering methods, Fuzzy Classification, Clustering and pattern recognition

Explore Pandas Library for Data Summarization

Demonstrate the basic concept of Perceptron using Python.

Demonstrate the use case of different transfer functions (Binary Step, Sigmoid, Relu, Tanh, Softmax) in Artificial Neural Network using Python.

Demonstrate the use of Perceptron for deploying Logic Gate: AND, OR, NOR, NAND, XOR

Demonstrate the solution of XOR GATE (Non-Linearly Separable Problem) using ANN.

Demonstrate Multi-Layer Perceptron Backpropagation using Python.

Implement the concept of Fuzzy Logic.

Demonstrate basic fuzzy operations using Python (Union, Intersection, Complement)

Demonstrate generation of fuzzy values using three different membership functions.

Demonstrate Genetic Algorithm using Python.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Experiment with various soft computing techniques and analyse the per- formance of neural network model using various evaluation metrics. | K4 |
| C02 | Explain evolutionary computation and apply it for solving optimization problems. | K3 |
| C03 | Experiment with genetic algorithm and apply genetic operators in vari-ous applications. | K3 |
| C04 | Explain fuzzy systems and contrast fuzzification and defuzzificationtechniques. | K2 |
| C05 | Classify and compare various soft computing methods. | K2 |

Deepa, S.N. and Sivanandam, S.N., “Principles of Soft Computing, 2 nd Edition”, Wiley India, 2011.

Tom, Mitchell, “Machine Learning”, McGraw-Hill, 2017.

Zimmermann H. J. “Fuzzy set theory and its Applications” Springer international edition, 2011.

Timothy, J. Ross, “Fuzzy Logic with Engineering Applications, 3 rd Edition”, Wiley India, 2010.

Shai, Shalev-Shwartz, Shai, Ben-David, “Understanding Machine Learning from Theory to Algorithms”, Cambridge University Press, 2014.

Malik H, Iqbal A, Yadav AK. “Soft computing in condition monitoring and diagnostics of electrical and mechanical systems”. Berlin/Heidelberg, Germany: Springer; 2020.

Lesot M, Marsala C. “Fuzzy Approaches for Soft Computing and Approximate Reasoning: Theories and Applications”. Switzerland: Springer. 2020.

| Course Code | SEMS302 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Speech Signal Processing |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn the basic concepts of articulatory and acoustic phonetics.
• To study different techniques for speech analysis.
• To impart knowledge on speech modelling techniques and their implementation issues.
• To study various speech recognition techniques.
• To learn different speech synthesis techniques and their applications.

Fundamentals of Speech; Articulatory phonetics: production and classification of speech sounds; Acoustic phonetics: acoustics of speech production; Review of Digital Signal Processing; Short Time Fourier Transform (STFT); LPC Methods.

Introduction to Speech Analysis, Understanding about feature extraction and pattern comparison techniques, Speech distortion measures, mathematical and perceptual, log–spectral distance, Cepstral distances, weighted cepstral distances and filtering, Likelihood distortions, spectral distortion using a warped frequency scale, LPC, PLP and MFCC coefficients, Time alignment and normalization: dynamic time warping, Multiple time: alignment paths.

Introduction to Speech Modelling, Understanding Hidden Markov Models (HMMs), Markov Process, HMMS-2 evaluation, Optimal state sequence: viterbi search, Baum-Welch parameter re-estimation, Implementation issues.

Introduction to Speech Recognition, Architecture of a large vocabulary continuous speech recognition system, Acoustics and language models, N-gram language model, Context dependent sub-word units, Applications and present status.

Introduction to Speech Synthesis, Understanding the basics of Text-to-speech synthesis (TTS), Concatenative and waveform synthesis methods, Sub-word units for TTS, Understanding about intelligibility and naturalness, Role of prosody, Applications and present status.

Introduction to MATLAB on Speech Signal Processing.

Speech acquisition and recording using MATLAB.

Analysis of Different Sounds (Phonemes) using MATLAB.

Implement of Short Term Time Domain Processing of Speech using MATLAB.

Implementation of Linear Predictive Coding (LPC) methods in MATLAB.

Fundamental frequency estimation in Speech signal using MATLAB.

Format synthesis MFCC extraction from Speech signal using MATLAB.

Cepstral Analysis of Speech Signal in MATLAB.

LPCC extraction from Speech signal using MATLAB.

Implementation of HMM models for Speech Modelling in MATLAB.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain fundamentals of speech processing and classify differentspeech sounds. | K2 |
| C02 | Apply feature extraction and pattern comparison techniques of speechprocessing. | K3 |
| C03 | Apply hidden markov model for optimal state sequence search andwelch parameter re-estimation. | K3 |
| C04 | Analyze architecture of a large vocabulary continuous speech recogni-tion system. | K4 |
| C05 | Compare and select methods for waveform and text-to-speech synthe-sis. | K5 |

Rabiner, L. and Schafer, R., “Theory and Applications of Digital Speech Processing”, 1st edition, Pearson Education, 2010.

Rabiner, L. R., Juang, B. H., and Yegnararayana, B., “Fundamentals of Speech Recognition”, 1st edition, Pearson Education, 2008

Jurafsky, D. and Martin, J. H., “Speech and Language Processing”, 2nd edition, Pearson Education, 2013.

Quatieri, Thomas F. ”Discrete-time speech signal processing: principles and practice”, Pearson Education India, 2002.

| CourseCode | SCMS401 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Deep Learning |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course 'Type | MS |

• To understand the core principles of deep learning and neural networks.

• To develop proficiency in building and training convolutional neural networks (CNNs).

• To gain knowledge of sequence modeling techniques, including recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and LSTM networks.

• To explore advanced deep learning architectures like transformers and auto-encoders.

• To familiarize with the latest advancements in deep learning, including generative adversarial networks (GANs) and large language models.

Unit I: Basics of Deep Networks

Deep Networks: Gradient-based Learning, Hidden Units, Architecture Design, Back-Propagation, Regularization, Activation functions, Training Deep Models, Hyper-parameters, Optimization.

Motivation, Applications, Convolution Operations, CNN layers: Convolutional layer, activation layer, pooling layer, flattening, CNN architecture: 1D-CNN, 2D-CNN, 3D-CNN. Pretrained models: VGG16, ResNet50.

Motivation, Applications, Recurrent Neural Networks, Bidirectional RNNs, Encoder-Decoder Sequence-to-Sequence architecture, Deep Recurrent Networks, Recursive Neural Networks, Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Bi-LSTM.

Transformers: Motivation, Applications, Attention-mechanism, encoder-decoder architecture, BERT Model. Autoencoders: Undercomplete Autoencoders, Regularized Autoencoders, Representational power, Layer Size and Depth, Stochastic Encoders and Decoders, Denoising Encoders., Applications of Autoencoders.

Introduction to Generative AI, Generative Adversarial Networks, Large Language Models, Diffusion models, Neuromorphic computing.

Implementation of Perceptron Network

Implementation of Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) and Hyperparameter Tuning

Implementation of Multilayer Neural Network using Keras and Data Augmentation on
MNIST Dataset

Implementation of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) on MNIST Dataset.

Implementation of Pretrained Transfer Learning Models for Plant Disease Detection

Implementation of Autoencoder on MNIST Dataset for Handwritten Digit Recognition

Implementation of Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) for Sentiment Analysis

Implementation of LSTM for Text Generation

Implementation of GAN for Generating Handwritten Digits on MNIST Dataset

Implementation of Capsule Networks for Image Classification

Implementation of U-Net for Image Segmentation

Implementation of Object Detection Using YOLOv7

Implementation of ResNet Architecture for Image Classification

Implementation of Spatial and Channel Attention in CNN

Implementation of Bidirectional LSTM for Named Entity Recognition (NER)

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Develop and deploy deep neural networks for real-world problem solv- ing, mastering model training and optimization. | K3 |
| C02 | Employ convolutional neural networks to ensure high accuracy and ef-ficiency for different classification/regression task. | K2 |
| C03 | Utilize sequence modeling to capture temporal dependencies and en-hance performance in sequential prediction tasks. | K4 |
| CO4 | Implement advanced architectures like transformers and autoencodersfor tasks such as language understanding,language translation. | K4 |
| C05 | Explore the emerging technologies in deep learning like GANs, LLM. | K2 |

Bengio, Yoshua, Ian Goodfellow, and Aaron Courville. “Deep learning”. Cambridge, MA, USA: MIT press, 2017. 2. Zhang, Aston, et al. “Dive into deep learning”. Cambridge University Press, 2023.

Wani, M. Arif, et al. “Advances in deep learning”. Springer, 2020.

Huang, Kaizhu, et al., “Deep learning: fundamentals, theory and applications”. Vol. 2.
springer, 2019.

Chollet, Francois. “Deep learning with Python”. Simon and Schuster, 2021.

Foster, David. “Generative deep learning”. ” O’Reilly Media, Inc.”, 2022.

heading_path: Unit IV: Cloud and FOG Computing in IOT
content:
| Course Code | SEMS401 |
| --- | --- |
| Course Title | Introduction to IoT |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-0-2-4 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To understand the fundamentals of IoT and Networking concepts.
• To familiarize with IoT architecture, sensors, actuators, device design, and the considerations involved in building IoT-enabled systems.
• To provide knowledge about various IoT communication technologies, including constrained devices, low-power networks, and key protocols for data transmission.
• To explore how cloud, fog, and edge computing architectures support IoT applications.
• To examine practical IoT applications in fields such as agriculture, healthcare, and transportation.

Basics of networking (types of networks, layered models, addressing, TCP/IP transport layer), Introduction to the architecture of wireless sensor networks, Machine-to-Machine (M2M) communication and cyber physical systems. Introduction to IoT and its comparison with M2M, WSN and CPS. IoT networking components, Addressing strategies in IoT.

Introduction to IoT Sensors and their characteristics, Sensing types and their considerations, Introduction to IoT Actuators, their types and characteristics, IoT processing topologies, their types and its importance, Data formatting, Processing topologies, IoT device design and selection considerations, Processing offloading, IoT connectivity technologies.

Introduction to nodes, Constrained nodes and network, and the type of devices, Low power and lossy networks, Infrastructure protocols, Discovery protocols, Data protocols, Identification protocols, Device management protocols, Sematic protocols, IoT interoperability standards and frameworks.

Introduction to cloud computing, Virtualization, Cloud Models, SLA in cloud computing, Cloud implementation in Sensor – Cloud, Introduction to fog computing and its architecture, Fog computing in IoT, Application of fog computing in IoT, Edge computing in IoT.

IoT applications in agriculture, vehicular networks and healthcare, IoT analytics, Uses of machine learning in IoT, Advantages and challenges of ML in IoT, ML algorithms for IoT applications, Performance metrices for evaluating ML algorithms.

Study the fundamental of IOT softwares and components.

Familiarization with Arduino/Raspberry Pi and perform necessary software.

To interface LED/Buzzer with Arduino/Raspberry Pi and write a program to turn ON LED for 1 sec after every 2 seconds.

To interface Push button/Digital sensor (IR/LDR) with Arduino/Raspberry Pi and write a program to turn ON LED when push button is pressed or at sensor detection.

To interface DHT11 sensor with Arduino/Raspberry Pi and write a program to print temperature and humidity readings.

To interface motor using relay with Arduino/Raspberry Pi and write a program to turn ON motor when push button is pressed.

Write a program on Arduino/Raspberry Pi to retrieve temperature and humidity data from thingspeak cloud.

To install MySQL database on Raspberry Pi and perform basic SQL queries

Write a program to create UDP server on Arduino/Raspberry Pi and respond with humidity data to UDP client when requested.

Write a program to create TCP server on Arduino/Raspberry Pi and respond with humidity data to TCP client when requested.

Total Periods: $4 0 + 2 4 = 6 4$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Associate and classify the architecture of various communication sys-tems. | K2 |
| C02 | Elaborate the IoT infrastructure and data processing methodologies. | K2 |
| C03 | Interpret the various networking protocols used in IoT. | K2 |
| C04 | Acquire the concepts of fog and cloud computing in IoT. | K3 |
| C05 | Illustrate the various real-life applications of IoT. | K3 |

Misra, S., Mukherjee, A. and Roy, A. Introduction to IoT. Cambridge University Press, 2021.

Serpanos, D. and Wolf, M. Internet-of-things (IoT) systems: architectures, algorithms, methodologies. Springer, 2017.

Xiao, P. Designing Embedded Systems and the Internet of Things (IoT) with the ARM mbed. John Wiley & Sons, 2018.

Hersent, O., Boswarthick D., and Elloumi, O., The Internet of Things: Key Applications and Protocols. John Wiley & Sons, 2011.

| Course Code | SCMS402 |
| --- | --- |
| Course'Title | Cyber Physical Systems |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-0-3 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To understand the basic principles behind cyber physical systems.

• To understand the control theory of cyber physical systems.

• To understand the hardware platform components for Cyber Physical Systems

• To understand the implementation issues related to cyber-physical systems.

• To understand applications of cyber physical systems to expose new opportunities.

Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) in the real world, Basic principles of design and validation of CPS, Industry 4.0 AutoSAR, IIOT implications, Building Automation, Medical CPS, Basic Techniques, Problem Definition, Solving the Synthesis Problem, Construction of Symbolic Models, Advanced Techniques, Software Tools.

Mathematical modelling of electrical systems, mechanical systems, electro-mechanical systems. Laplace transforms, transfer functions, electrical analogues of other dynamical systems. State-space modelling of dynamical systems. Block diagrams, block diagram reductions. Signal flow graph, Mason’s gain formula. Linearity, time-invariance versus nonlinearity and timevariance. Linearization. Distributed parameter systems, Feedback Control Systems, Basic Techniques, Controller Timing, Controller Design for resource efficiency

CPS HW platforms - Processors, Sensors, Actuators CPS Network – Wireless Hart, CAN, Automotive Ethernet Scheduling Real Time CPS tasks: Table-driven and Event driven schedulers Hybrid schedulers. Dynamical Systems and Stability Controller Design Techniques Performance under Packet drop and Noise

From features to automotive software components Mapping software components to ECUs. CPS Performance Analysis: Effect of scheduling, bus latency, sense and actuation faults on control performance, network congestion Building real-time networks for CPS Cyber Security Requirements, Attack Model, Countermeasures, Advanced Techniques, System Theoretic Approaches.

Medical Cyber-Physical Systems, Energy Cyber-Physical Systems, Cyber-Physical Systems Built on Wireless Sensor Networks.

Total Periods: 40

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Construct the basic models for a given cyber physical system. | K3 |
| C02 | Design a controller system to improve resource efficiency. | K6 |
| C03 | Inspect the hardware requirements of various cyber physical systems. | K4 |
| C04 | Inspect the implementation issues of the CPS. | K2 |
| C05 | Assess the application of cyber physical systems in different domains. | K5 |

Rajkumar R., Dionisio de Niz and Klein M., “Cyber-Physical Systems”, First Edition, Addison-Wesley Professional, 2017.

Platzer, A., 2018. Logical foundations of cyber-physical systems (Vol. 662). Cham: Springer.

Rajeev Alur, “Principles of Cyber-Physical Systems”, MIT Press, 2015. 2. Roy S. and Sajal K. Das, “Principles of Cyber-Physical Systems: An Interdisciplinary Approach”, Cambridge University Press, 2020.

| Course Code | SEMS402 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Biomedical Signal Processing |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-0-0-3 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn types, sources, acquisition, and analysis of biomedical signals.
• To learn electrocardiography and electromyography, including systems, signals, and processing techniques.
• To learn to identify artifacts and noise in various biosignal processes.
• To understand digital filtering, FIR and IIR filters, and their design.
• To Learn signal averaging, ECG QRS detection, and related analysis techniques.

The nature of biomedical signals, examples of biomedical signals, action potential, electroneurogram (ENG), electromyogram signal (EMG), electrocardiogram (ECG), electroencephalogram (EEG), event-related potentials (ERPs), The electrogastrogram (EGG), phonocardiogram (PCG), carotid pulse (CP), speech signal, objectives of biomedical signal analysis, difficulties in biomedical signal processing, what is medical instrument, computer- aided diagnostics.

Basic electrocardiography, ECG leads systems, ECG signal characteristics, concurrent, coupled and correlated processes.

ELECTROMYOGRAPHY: Muscular system, Electrical signals of the motor unit and gross muscle, Human motor coordination system, Electrodes, Correlation of force and work; EMG integrators, Signals conditioning & processing.

Random noise, structured noise, and physiological interference, stationary Vs non-stationary processes. Noise in event-related potentials, high-frequency noise in ECG, motion artifacts in ECG, power-line interference in ECG signals, and maternal interference in fetal ECG.

Digital filters, z transform, elements of a digital filter, types of digital filters, the transfer function of difference equation, the $\mathbf { Z }$ -plane pole-zero plot, the rubber membrane concept. FINITE IMPULSE RESPONSE FILTERS: Characteristics of FIR filters, smoothing filters, notch filters, derivatives, window design, frequency sampling, and minimax design. INFINITE IMPULSE RESPONSE FILTERS: Generic equations of IIR filters, simple one-pole example, integrators, and design methods for two-pole filters.

Basics of signal averaging, signal averaging as a digital filter, a typical average, software for signal averaging, limitations of signal averaging. ECG QRS DETECTION: Power spectrum of the ECG, band pass filtering techniques, differentiation techniques, template matching techniques, A QRS detection algorithm. ECG interpretation, ST- segment analyzer, portable arrhythmia monitor.

Total Periods: 40

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| Co | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Knowledge of fundamental background for biomedical signal process-ing leading towards automatic disease diagnostics. | K2 |
| C02 | Interpret ECG and EMG systems, signals, and processing techniqueseffectively. | K2 |
| C03 | Detect and manage random, structured, and physiological artifacts invarious biosignal processes. | K6 |
| C04 | Understanding of basic digital filtering techniques and ability to designvarious types of filters. | K4 |
| C05 | Ability to detect and analyze ECG signals by QRS algorithm. | K4 |

Rangayyan, R. M., “Biomedical Signal Analysis”, 2nd edition, Wiley, 2016. 2. Tompkins, W. J., “Biomedical Digital Signal Processing: C Language Examples and Laboratory. Experiments for the IBM PC”, Prentice-Hall India, 1998. 3. D C Reddy, “Biomedical Digital Signal Processing”, McGraw Hills, 2005.

Bruce, E. N., “Biomedical Signal Processing and Signal Modeling”, Wiley, 2007. 2. Semmlow, J. L. and Griffel, B., “Biosignal and Medical Image Processing”, 3rd edition, CRC press, 2014.

| Course Code | SCMS403 |
| --- | --- |
| Course 'Title | Introduction to Federated Learning |
| Number of Credits(L-T-P-C) | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn distributed machine learning.

• To explore the basics of federated learning.

• To learn with the various types of Federated learnings.

• To apply the federated learning concepts in various applications like transfer learning, computer vision, and natural language processing.

• To explore with different federated learning frameworks for their implementation

Unit I: Distributed Machine Learning

Introduction to Distributed Learning, Scalability- motivated Distributed Machine Learning, Privacy Motivated Distributed Machine Learning, Privacy-Preserving Distributed Machine Learning, Privacy-Preserving Gradient Descent, Distributed Learning Vs Federated Learning.

Federated Learning as a solution: Motivation and Challenges, Current development in Federated Learning, Classification of Federated Learning, Frameworks of Federated Learning, Privacy-preserving Machine Learning, Privacy-preserving Machine Learning vs Secure Machine Learning, Threats and Security Model.

Horizontal Federated Learning: Definition, Architecture, Federated Averaging algorithm, Improvement in Federated Averaging algorithm, Research Challenges. Vertical Federated Learning: Definition, Architecture, Algorithms, and Challenges.

Federated Transfer Learning (FTL), FTL Framework and Challenges. Federated CV: Introduction, Application, and Challenges. Federated NLP: Introduction, Application, and Challenges. Federated Recommendation: Recommendation Model, Federated Recommendation Systems, Application, and Challenges.

Case Studies: Finance, Healthcare, Education, Urban Computing, and Smart City. Federated Learning Tools: TensorFlow Federated, Layers of TensorFlow Federated, Installation and Setup, Model Building, Computation Building, and Model Aggregation.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Understand the basis of distributed machine learning. | K1 |
| C02 | Understand the basics of federated learning. | K1 |
| C03 | Apply suitable federated learning techniques for an application. | K3 |
| C04 | Design and develop an efficient federated learning system for an appli-cation. | K5 |
| C05 | Implement an effective learning system for the various application do-main. | K4 |

Qiang Yang, Yang Liu, Yong Cheng, Yan Kang, Tianjian Chen, and Han Yu: “Federated Learning”, Morgan and Claypool Publishers, 2020.

Yaochu Jin, Hangyu Zhu, Jinjin Xu, and Yang Chen: “Federated Learning: Fundamentals and Advances”, Springer, 2020.

Saravanan Krishnan, A. Jose Anand, R. Srinivasan, R. Kavitha, S. Suresh. “Handbook on Federated Learning Advances, Applications and Opportunities”, CRC Press, 2024.

Ziller, Alexander, et al. “Pysyft: A library for easy federated learning.” Federated Learning Systems: Towards Next-Generation AI (2021): 111-139.

| Course Code | SEMS403 |
| --- | --- |
| CourseTitle | Quantum Computing |
| Number of Credits (L-T-P-C) | 3-1-0-4 |
| Course Type | MS |

• To learn the mathematical foundations of quantum computing.

• To understand the basic principles of model of computations in quantum world.

• To learn the key concepts of quantum mechanics for solving computing problems.

• To apply quantum mechanics concepts for solving significant computing problems.

• To understand quantum noise and correction techniques.

Overview of traditional computing, Church-Turing Thesis, Circuit model of computation, reversible computation, Dirac notation, complex inner and Hilbert spaces, Hermitian and Unitary operators, Dual vectors, tensor products, polar and singular value decompositions, the spectral theorem, Schmidt decomposition theorem.

Postulates of quantum mechanics, state space, time evolution of a closed system, measurement, dynamics, composite systems, Bits and Qubits as vector spaces, unary quantum operators – single qubit gates, Bloch sphere, mixed states and density matrices, multiple qubits and multiqubit gates, Universal quantum gates, quantum black-box model, quantum circuit complexities – gates, qubits, depth, query.

No-cloning theorem, dense coding, quantum teleportation, quantum parallelism and entanglement, phase kickback, Deutsch algorithm, Deutsch-Jozsa algorithm, Bernstein-Vazirani algorithm, Simon’s algorithm, Quantum Key Distribution – BB84 protocol, Simulation of quantum systems

Unit IV: Quantum Algorithms Quantum integral transform, quantum Fourier transform (QFT), application of QFT – Period-finding, Shor’s factorization algorithm, quantum phase estimation, discrete logarithm solution, hidden subgroup solution, Grover’s search, optimality of quantum search, amplitude amplification, quantum counting, minimum and maximum finding algorithms.

Decoherence, open quantum system, errors – bit-flip, phase-flip, depolarizing, amplitude-damping,

Lindblad equation, Quantum Error Correction Codes (QECC) – 3-qubit bit-flip QECC, 3-qubit phase-flip QECC, Shor’s 9-qubit QECC, Hamming QECC, 7-qubits and 5-qubits QECC.

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| CO | Description | Level |
| --- | --- | --- |
| C01 | Explain the fundamentals of quantum computing and relevant mathe-matical ideas. | K2 |
| C02 | Understand formal model of computation for quantum computing andcomponents for constructing quantum circuits. | K2 |
| C03 | Explain primary concepts of quantum computing used for solving math-ematical and computing problems. | K3 |
| C04 | Solve significant computing problems using quantum mechanical phe-nomenon. | K3 |
| C05 | Understand decoherence and error correction techniques for fault toler-ant quantum systems. | K2 |

M. A. Nielsen and I. L. Chuang, “Quantum Computation and Quantum Information,” Cambridge University Press, 2010.

N. D. Mermin, “Quantum Computer Science: An Introduction (1st ed.),” Cambridge University Press, 2007.

Nakahara and T. Ohmi, “Quantum Computing – From Linear Algebra to Physical Realizations (1st ed.),” CRC Press, 2008.

R. T. Perry, “Quantum Computing from the Ground Up (1st ed.),” World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd., 2012

III. No. of maximum exits: one other than normal. IV. No. of maximum entry: one other than normal. V. Maximum gap between exit and entry: two years (integral only). VI. Academic Bank of Credits will be maintained

It is mandatory for the student to register for four theory and three lab courses from I to V semester. The student should undergo industrial training/ internship for a minimum period of five months during the VI semester. In the VII semester, student will register for four theory courses and a lab course, while in the VIII semester three theory courses are mandatory. Project Work will be carried out in the V, VII, and VIII semesters.

Design of curriculum consists of the following components of study:

This group of courses consists of Mathematics, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Professional Communication, Basic Environmental Science and Engineering, Humanities, Signals and Systems, and Computer Programming. Students may choose a management elective subject out of total four subjects mentioned in the curriculum.

The PC consists of 9 courses which comprise of both theory and lab components and 2 lab courses specifically for programming. The PC comprises a total number of 49 credits (31 Theories + 18 Labs). All the PC courses will be covered in first two years which covers almost the GATE syllabus.

The total number of 6 PE will be offered in V, VII, and VIII semesters. Students will have to choose one out of two subjects as per their choice. The PE consists of six theory courses out of which three courses comprise labs. The PE comprises a total number of 24 credits (18 Theories $+ 6$ Labs).

The Institute offers common SE to all the departments. School of Electronics is offering two streams i.e., Cyber Physical Systems and Intelligent Systems. Moreover, Applications, Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, Database and Networking, and Security streams are offered by the School of Computing. A total number of 30 subjects will be offered in V, VII, and VIII semesters. The subjects are grouped into six streams and further, each elective comprises five number of subjects, one from each stream. Students will have to choose one out of six subjects as per their choice.

The curriculum has the support for internship in the adjoining V semester for a minimum period of five months in any of the reputed Industries/ Academic Institutes/ R&D Organizations. Students may identify the industries considering their career choice. Evaluation will be conducted as per the Clause 10.2 of Academic Rules. Attachment with an academic institution within the country (IISc/IITs/NITs/IIITs and CFTIs) or foreign universities are also permitted in lieu of industrial training.

This is a semester project work included in I to IV semester, having 3 credits in each semester. It consists of a practical problem or a project based on the combination of different labs studied in a corresponding semester.

The PW is designed as a single project for a total duration of three semesters, involving detailed literature survey, implementation plan, and experimentation plan. The percentage of overall project work should be approximately 15 and 35 in V and VII semester respectively. Remaining $50 \%$ of the work has to be completed or demonstrated in VIII semester. Evaluation will be conducted as per the Clause 10.3 of Academic Rules.

This course is optional for students who opt for B.Tech. (Honors). The students having $\mathrm { S G P A } { \geq } 8 . 0$ (Semester I to IV) are eligible for the Honors Course. The students can also choose online courses from NPTEL/SWAYAM/MOOCs/etc,. They should undergo the online course completely, submit assignments, projects, etc. and appear for the final exam conducted by the online instructor. The awarded grade must be submitted for the award of suitable letter grade in this course.

This course is optional for students who opt for B.Tech. (Optional). Students who don’t fulfil the eligibility criteria for Honors can opt for Optional Course. The students can choose online courses from NPTEL/SWAYAM/MOOCs/etc,. In Optional course the

credit will not be counted for the calculation of the final CGPA but the credit will appear in the Grade card and transcript.

L-T-P-C ⇒ Lecture – Tutorial – Practicum/Practical – Credits
Credit structure of each course is given in L-T-P-C form (e.g., 2–1–0–3). The numbers corresponding to L, T and $\mathrm { P }$ denote the contact hours per week for Lecture, Tutorial and Practical/Practicum respectively, and that of C denotes the total number of credits for that course in a semester.

The Institute follows relative grading with flexibility given to teachers to decide the mark ranges for grades. All assessment of a course will be done on the basis of marks.

The students shall be placed in any of the bands with letter grades: ‘S’, ‘A’, ‘B’, ‘C’, ‘D’, ‘E’ and ‘I’ with the credit points of $^ { \cdot } 1 0 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 9 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 8 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 7 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 6 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 5 ^ { \cdot } , { } ^ { \cdot } 0 ^ { \cdot }$ , respectively.

The cut-off mark for completion of a course shall be calculated as $\frac { \overline { { X } } } { 2 }$ where $\overline { { X } }$ is the mean of the class. Students scoring marks above the cut-off mark shall be appropriately placed in top six bands typically 10, 15, 25, 25, 15, 10 percentages respectively. Students scoring less than cut-off mark shall be placed in lower most band (‘I’).

Teachers can adopt any one of the following logical methods to decide the grades: (a) Normalized curve, (b) Z-score, and (c) Gap theory.

heading_path: PHC122 ELECTRICITY, MAGNETISM AND QUANTUM MECHANICS

content:
To impart knowledge about the limitations of Newtonian Mechanics and alternate formalism of Lagrange and Hamilton and the concept of special relativity and its applications to physical sciences and engineering.
To study the basic principles of quantum mechanics: Learn how to solve the Schrödinger’s equation and its applications.
To understand the basic framework of solid-state physics.
To recognize and classify the structures of Optical fibre and types.
To apprise the students regarding the concepts of electrodynamics and Maxwell equations and use them in various situations

UNIT 1: CLASSICAL MECHANICS

08

i) Review: Newtonian Mechanics in Rectilinear Coordinate System, Motion in Plane Polar Coordinates, Conservation Principles, Inertial and Non-inertial Frames, Rigid Body Dynamics. Introductory ideas about Lagrangian and Hamiltonian and their simple applications.

ii) Special Theory of Relativity (STR). Michelson-Morley Experiment, Postulates of STR, Galilean Transformation, Lorentz Transformation, Simultaneity, Length Contraction, Time Dilation, Relativistic Addition of Velocities, Mass-Energy Equivalence, Energy-Momentum Relationships.

08

i) Basics of Quantum Physics: Origin of Quantum Theory, Planck’s Quantum Theory, Black Body Radiation, Photoelectric Effect, Compton Effect, WaveParticle Duality: De Broglie Wavelength, Group and Phase Velocity, Heisenberg’s uncertainty Principle, Double Slit Experiment, Schrödinger Equation, Physical interpretation of Wave Function, Elementary Idea of Operators, Eigen-Value Problem, Solution of Schrödinger Equation for simple boundary value problems, Reflection and Transmission Coefficients, Tunnelling, Particle in a three Dimensional Box, Degenerate States.

ii) Quantum Statistics: Maxwell-Boltzmann, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac Statistics. Density of States. Applications of B-E statistics: LASER (Spontaneous and Stimulated Emissions & Absorption, Einstein’s Coefficients, Population Inversion, LASER Systems: Ruby LASER, He-Ne LASER, Semiconductor LASER-applications), Bose-Einstein Condensation. Applications of F-D Statistics: Free Electron Model of electrons in metals. Concept of Fermi Energy. Elementary Ideas of Band Theory of Solids.

08

i) Structure of Materials: Space Lattice and Unit Cells, Crystal System, Symmetry Operation, Miller Indices, Packing Fractions, Structure Determination using X-ray Diffraction, Bragg’s Law.

ii) Semiconductor: Direct and indirect band gap semiconductors, Electron and Hole concentrations, Doping n-type, p-type, temperature variation of carrier concentration, Fermi level, Zener Diode, Tunnel Diodes, Photodiodes, Light Emitting Diodes. Hall Effect, Superconductors.

iii) Magnetic and Dielectric Properties of Materials: Origin of Magnetism, Dia, Para, Ferro, Anti-Ferro and Ferrimagnetism, Soft and Hard Magnetic Materials, Dielectric Properties.

08

Fermat’s principle and Snell’s law-optical fiber, Principle and construction, Acceptance cone, Numerical aperture, V-Number, Types of fibers, Fabrication: Double crucible technique, Fiber optic communication principle, Fiber optic sensors.

08

i) Electrostatics: Coulomb’s Law, Gauss’s Law, proof of Gauss’s Law, Electrostatic Field in Matter: Dielectric Polarization, polarizability and susceptibility, Types of Polarization, Claussius-Mossotti Equation.

ii) Magnetostatics: Lorentz Force, Equation of Continuity, Biot-Savart Law, Ampere’s Law, Magnetostatic field in matter: Torques and forces on magnetic dipoles, Magnetization, Induction, Maxwell’s Equations, Propagation of EM Waves in Free Space.

To find the moment of inertia of a given flywheel.

To find the value of charge carrier concentration and Hall coefficient.

To determine the value of Planck’s constant.

To find the value of wavelength of a given light source using Michelson Interferometer.

To find the value of wavelength of a given light source using Newton’s rings.

To verify the Biot-Savart Law using the circular coil carrying current.

To find the resonance frequency in a series LCR circuit.

To find the resonance frequency in a parallel LCR circuit.

To determine the value of Stefan’s constant using black body radiation.

To determine the value of $\mathrm { { e / m } }$ ratio.

To find the energy gap of a material of p-n junction.

To study the Rutherford scattering of alpha particles.

To determine the plateau and optimal operating voltage of a Geiger-Müller

To determine the wavelength of a given LASER source using Diffraction Grating.

To study the interaction of high energy photons with matter.

To find the value of time constant of an RC circuit.

To study the charging and discharging of a Capacitor.

To study the I-V characteristics of a Solar cell.

To study the polarization of light.

To study the B-H hysteresis curve.

Total Periods: $\mathbf { 4 0 + 4 8 } = \mathbf { 8 8 }$

After the completion of this course, students will be able to:

| | Identify the role of virtual work, Lagrange's and Hamilton's approach to the CO1 : mechanics and develop skills to impart practical knowledge and apply the knowledge of Special Theory of Relativity. |
| --- | --- |
| C02 | Describe and analyze the dynamics of systems that move under the influence of given potential, and to make use of the basics of Quantum Mechanics. |
| practical knowledge. | Apply principles to determine crystal structure, thermal behavior of solids, CO3: dielectric, electric and magnetic behavior of solids,and develop skils to impart |
| C04: | Demonstrate optical fiber communication link， structure, propagation and transmission properties of an optical fiber. |
| C05 | (K3) Apply the concepts related to Faraday's law, induced emf and Maxwell's equations. (K3) |
